docs.title: Definition and Misuse
docs.text:
• The term exploitation is often used without a clear definition, simply to express disapproval of prices or wages.
  • It should be understood as a statement about personal emotional reactions rather than a factual claim.

docs.title: Examples of Misconceptions
docs.text:
• Higher prices in low-income neighborhoods are not necessarily exploitative; they may be due to economic factors such as higher costs for local stores.
  • Low pay for Third World workers is not necessarily exploitation; it may reflect different market conditions and economic realities.

docs.title: Theoretical Framework
docs.text:
• Exploitation theories assume that some individuals or groups can receive more than their fair share of compensation by:
    • Charging consumers more than necessary
    • Paying employees less than necessary
  • However, this assumption requires careful examination and consideration of real-world circumstances.

docs.title: Key Takeaway
docs.text: • To understand exploitation, it is essential to analyze the underlying economic factors and market conditions rather than relying on emotional reactions or assumptions.

docs.title: Summary Notes
docs.text:
Above-Average Returns on Investment

  • Earning a rate of return on investment greater than what is required to compensate for risks and contributions will attract others who want to share in the profits.
  • This increased competition will drive above-average rates of return back down due to expanded investment and production.

Barriers to Entry

  • Governments are common and effective barriers to new competition.
  • Regulations and controls can prevent new entrants and allow existing firms to maintain above-average earnings on investment.

Real-World Example

  • During World War II, the British colonial government in West Africa imposed trade controls, leading to large profits for existing traders.
  • These controls prevented new firms from entering the market, reserving high profits for those already established.

Key Points

  • Above-average returns on investment attract competition, which drives rates of return back down.
  • Barriers to entry, such as government regulations and controls, can prevent new entrants and maintain above-average earnings for existing firms.

docs.title: Government Restrictions on Entry
docs.text:
• Governments have restricted entry into various occupations and industries, both nationally and locally.
  • This has been a common practice globally, with varying degrees of restriction.

docs.title: Historical Precedents
docs.text:
• In the past, monarchs would often grant monopoly rights to favored individuals or enterprises for specific commodities like salt or wine.
  • These monopolies were sometimes granted as favors, but often required payment.

docs.title: Effects of Barriers to Entry
docs.text:
• Restricted entry leads to higher earnings than what would exist under free market competition.
  • This can be considered exploitation of consumers, as they pay more than necessary for products or services.

docs.title: Caveats
docs.text:
• Higher earnings do not always mean exploitation, as inefficient firms may survive under government protection despite being uncompetitive in a free market.
  • Even modest returns received by these firms represent consumer overpayment.

docs.title: Definition of Exploitation
docs.text:
• Situations where prices are higher than necessary to supply goods or services
  • Paying workers less than what they would receive in a free market or the amount necessary to attract continuing supply of people with their skills and talents

docs.title: Examples of Exploitation
docs.text:
• Large corporations charging high prices due to lack of competition, driving smaller firms out of business
  • Paying workers lower wages than their market value, more common among high-skilled workers than low-skilled ones

docs.title: The Case of Babe Ruth
docs.text:
• Defined as the difference between wealth created and amount paid, Babe Ruth may be considered one of the most exploited individuals in history
  • His performances generated huge revenue for the New York Yankees, building a dynasty that dominated baseball for decades
  • Despite this, he was likely underpaid compared to his market value

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: Exploitation can occur in various forms in free markets, and it's essential to recognize these situations to promote fair competition and equitable compensation.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Babe Ruth's contract with the Yankees allowed the team to exploit his services without having to bid against other teams.
  • The prevention of competition is essential for exploitation to occur.
  • Workers who have skills that are in high demand, such as doctors, can be less exploited due to their ability to seek employment elsewhere.

docs.title: Exploitation and Competition
docs.text: The case of Babe Ruth's contract with the Yankees illustrates how the absence of competition can lead to exploitation. With exclusive contracts, teams did not have to bid for players' services, allowing them to pay lower salaries than they would have otherwise. In contrast, unskilled workers who had alternative employment options were less likely to be exploited.

docs.title: Professional Exploitation
docs.text: Professionals like doctors are often invested in their careers and may accept lower pay initially due to high education costs and foregone earnings during training. However, this investment can also make them more susceptible to exploitation if salaries are set too low, potentially deterring others from entering the profession.

docs.title: Government Intervention
docs.text: In government-run systems, salary scales and pay rates for specific treatments or services can be set by authorities. If these rates are not sufficient to attract qualified individuals, it may lead to a shortage of skilled professionals in that field.

docs.title: Factors Leading to Exploitation
docs.text:
• Existing doctors have limited alternatives due to high education and training costs, making them unlikely to switch professions.
  • Low-paid workers may be unable to move or face high transportation costs, limiting their options.
  • Government-subsidized housing can also limit mobility for low-paid workers.

docs.title: Historical Precedents
docs.text:
• Slaves were exploited through force.
  • Indentured servants and contract laborers faced high moving costs, making them vulnerable to exploitation.
  • Some contract workers chose to continue working in poor conditions, suggesting that their current situation was preferable to alternatives.

docs.title: Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Exploitation can occur when individuals have limited alternatives or face significant barriers to mobility.
  • Low-paid workers may be particularly vulnerable due to these factors.
  • Understanding the root causes of exploitation is essential for addressing these issues.

docs.title: Notes on Exploitation in Labor Markets
docs.text:
Key Points

  • Exploitation can occur when there is only one employer for a particular kind of labor, allowing them to set lower pay scales.
  • This is more likely to happen to highly specialized and skilled workers, rather than unskilled workers who have multiple employment options.
  • The spread of low-cost transportation has reduced the likelihood of isolated local labor markets with only one employer.

Barriers to Entry or Exit

  • Barriers to entry or exit can lead to exploitation, particularly in situations where it is difficult or expensive for individuals or businesses to leave a particular location or occupation.
  • Examples include:
    • Slaves who are unable to exit their situation
    • Doctors who have invested heavily in education and training and may find it difficult to change careers
    • Businesses that have invested large amounts of capital in a particular location, such as a hydroelectric dam

Exploitation beyond Traditional Definitions

  • The term exploitation can apply to individuals and businesses beyond traditional definitions, including:
    • Highly skilled workers who are limited by their specialized skills
    • Businesses that are tied to a particular location due to high fixed costs

docs.title: Exploitation in the Labor Market
docs.text:
• In the long run, businesses tend to avoid investing in places with unfavorable political climates.
  • Those who have already invested may accept lower returns rather than relocating.

docs.title: The Consequences of Misguided Policies
docs.text:
• Imposing price controls or minimum wage laws can harm consumers and workers if they are not actually being exploited.
  • Different consequences follow when policies are based on false beliefs versus true ones.

docs.title: Employer Cartels and Minimum Wage Laws
docs.text:
• In rare cases where an employer or small set of employers form a local cartel, government-imposed minimum wage increases may not result in job losses.
  • However, such cartels are difficult to maintain and have historically collapsed (e.g., postbellum South and 19th-century California).

docs.title: The Tendency to Regard Low-Paid Workers as Exploited
docs.text:
• While understandable, this tendency can lead to moral or political crusades that may not actually help workers.
  • Economist Henry Hazlitt's views on hiring salary are relevant to this discussion.

Key Points

  • Businesses tend to avoid unfavorable political climates in the long run.
  • Misguided policies can harm consumers and workers.
  • Employer cartels are rare and difficult to maintain.
  • The tendency to regard low-paid workers as exploited may lead to ineffective solutions.

docs.title: Poverty and Production
docs.text:
• The root problem of poverty is not distribution, but rather production.
  • The poor are poor because they are not producing enough, not because something is withheld from them. [1]
  • Solving poverty requires the cooperation of those in poverty, as well as others who may wish to help.

docs.title: Job Security
docs.text:
• Modern industrial nations face issues with job security.
  • Some countries have laws making it difficult and costly for private employers to fire anyone (e.g., France, Germany, India, South Africa).
  • Labor unions often push for job security policies in various industries and countries.
  • Teachers' unions in the United States are particularly successful at negotiating job security, making it expensive for school districts to fire teachers.

References

[1] Hazlitt

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
• Job security laws aim to reduce unemployment but may have opposite effects.
  • Countries with strong job protection laws often have higher unemployment rates.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Higher Unemployment Rates: France and South Africa, with strict job security laws, experience high unemployment rates (double-digit in France, 25%+ in South Africa).
  • Inefficient Hiring Practices: Laws make firing costly, leading to reduced hiring.
    • Firing is such a costly headache that many prefer not to hire in the first place - The Economist.
  • Industrial Society's Paradox: Efficiency and innovation lead to constant change, making it impossible for workers to maintain same jobs.
  • Historical Example: US agricultural industry transformed from 10 million farmers/farm laborers (1900s) to more efficient, productive systems.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: Job security laws may have unintended consequences, including higher unemployment rates and inefficient hiring practices. The need for constant innovation and adaptation in modern industrial society can make it challenging to maintain traditional job security measures.

docs.title: Soviet Economy's Inefficient Use of Resources
Key Points
docs.text:
• Workers in most Soviet enterprises were surplus and not efficiently utilized.
  • The Soviet economy used far more resources to produce a given amount of output compared to market economies like Japan and Germany.

docs.title: Statistics on Inefficiency
docs.text:
• 1 ton of copper production: 1,000 kilowatt hours of electrical energy (vs. 300 in West Germany)
  • 1 ton of cement production: twice the amount of energy used in Japan

docs.title: Root Cause of Inefficiency
docs.text:
• Lack of an economic system that makes efficient use of resources
  • No financial constraints on Soviet enterprises, leading to over-acquisition of machines and waste

docs.title: Consequences of Inefficiency
docs.text:
• Lower standard of living for the Soviet people
  • Waste of resources, with machines gathering dust or rusting away

docs.title: Changes in Farming and Labor Market
Changes in Farming
docs.text:
• By the late 20th century, farming became a radically different enterprise
  • Machinery, chemicals, and new methods reduced labor needs
  • Fewer farmers and farm laborers (less than one-fifth of the original number) could feed a population more than three times as large
  • Americans' biggest problems shifted from food scarcity to obesity and surplus agricultural produce

docs.title: Impact on Labor Market
docs.text:
• Farming job losses led to millions of workers moving into industry, increasing national output
  • No job security laws kept workers in agriculture, making them superfluous

docs.title: Broader Economic Changes
docs.text:
• New industries emerged (e.g., aviation, computers)
  • Old industries like retailing underwent radical changes
  • Companies and business methods evolved, with some surviving and others failing

docs.title: Job Market Trends
docs.text:
• Between 1990 and 1995, over 17 million workers in the United States lost their jobs
  • However, unemployment rates fell to record lows during the 1990s
  • Americans frequently changed jobs (average of nine jobs between ages 18 and 34)
  • In contrast, Europe had stronger job security laws and practices.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Job security laws in Europe are stronger than in the United States.
  • Despite this, job creation was slower in Europe during the 1990s, with the US creating jobs at triple the rate of European industrial nations.
  • Private sector jobs were actually lost in Europe, with only increased government employment leading to a net gain.

docs.title: The Impact of Job Security Laws
docs.text:
• Make it more expensive for companies to hire workers
  • Reduce labor demand due to higher costs
  • Save existing jobs but reduce economic flexibility and efficiency
  • Inhibit production of wealth needed for new job creation

docs.title: Consequences for Workers
docs.text:
• Existing employees may be worked overtime instead of hiring new workers during periods of rising demand
  • Capital substitution (e.g. using machines or technology) can lead to unemployment for other workers
  • No net increase in job security for the working population as a whole, but rather a concentration of insecurity on certain groups (e.g. younger workers, women re-entering the labor force)

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: Job security laws have unintended consequences that can actually worsen unemployment and economic outcomes. Understanding these connections is crucial for policymakers and the public alike.

docs.title: Job Security Laws and Minimum Wage Laws
docs.text:
• France's attempt to ease job security laws for first-time job holders led to riots by students at the Sorbonne and other French universities in 2006.
  • These laws are examples of government intervention in labor markets, differing from free competition.

docs.title: Occupational Licensing
docs.text:
• Laws require government-issued licenses to engage in certain occupations (e.g., physician or attorney).
  • Rationale: prevent untrained individuals from practicing these professions and committing fraud.
  • However, this power can be extended to other circumstances, far removed from the original rationale.

docs.title: History of Occupational Licensing
docs.text: • Economists explain how free competitive markets operate and then show how various infringements (like occupational licensing) affect them.

docs.title: Historical Development of Free Markets
docs.text:
• Controlled markets preceded free markets by centuries
  • Government permission was required for various occupations centuries ago
  • The rise of classical economics in the 19th century aided the growth of free markets

docs.title: Evolution of Labor and Product Markets
docs.text:
• Both labor and product markets became freer in the 19th century
  • Forces seeking protection from competition were never completely eradicated
  • More occupations required licenses over time, especially during economic downturns like the Great Depression

docs.title: Occupational Licensing
docs.text:
• Rationale for licensing: protect public from unqualified or unscrupulous practitioners
  • Demand for licensing usually comes from existing practitioners, not the public
  • Real purpose of licensing: protect existing practitioners from competition
  • Common practice: exempt existing practitioners from licensing requirements

docs.title: Forms of Occupational Licensing
docs.text: • Automatic issuance of licenses to applicants meeting certain criteria

docs.title: Occupational Licensing
docs.text:
• Requirement: Demonstrate competence in a particular occupation
  • Additional requirement: Clean record as a law-abiding citizen

docs.title: Types of Occupational Licenses
docs.text:
• Open Licensing: No numerical limit on licenses issued, e.g., medical doctors
  • Restricted Licensing: Numerical limit on licenses issued, regardless of qualified applicants, e.g., taxi drivers

docs.title: Example: Taxi Medallions in New York City
docs.text:
• Limiting the number of taxi licenses since 1937
  • Artificial scarcity of taxis leading to:
    • Rising cost of taxi medallions
      • Sold for $10 in 1937
      • Sold for $80,000 in the 1980s
      • Sold for over $1 million in 2011

  • Society investing in machinery and factories to increase future production
