• The national output of the United States at the beginning of the 20th century was vastly different from that at the end of the century (e.g. no airplanes, TVs, or computers in 1900)
  • Statistical comparisons between these two time periods are practically meaningless

docs.title: Gross Domestic Product (GDP)
docs.text: • Saying that GDP increased by X percent between 1900 and 2000 may not be meaningful when considering the vastly different goods and services included in national output at those times.

docs.title: Challenges in Measuring Real Income
docs.text:
• Statistics on economic growth can be misleading when comparing short-term changes (e.g., year-to-year)
  • The longer the time span, the more meaningless such statistics become
  • Attempts to measure real income are complicated by statistical adjustments with a built-in inflationary bias

docs.title: Limitations of the Consumer Price Index (CPI)
docs.text:
• The CPI measures the cost of living based on a collection of items commonly bought by most people
  • However, what people buy is affected by changes in prices and availability of goods over time
  • New goods are only included in the CPI after they become widely used, omitting their initial price declines

docs.title: Examples of Omitted Price Declines
docs.text:
• Videocassette recorders: initially sold for $30,000, later priced below $200, but only included in CPI after becoming widely used
  • Many other goods have followed a similar pattern, from luxury items to common consumer goods

docs.title: Implications
docs.text:
• Economic statistics may not accurately reflect changes in real income over time
  • The CPI may underestimate the impact of price declines on living standards

docs.title: Inflationary Bias in Consumer Price Index
Summary
docs.text:
The consumer price index (CPI) has an inflationary bias due to two main reasons:

  1. Quality improvements: Many goods increasing in price are also improving in quality, so the higher prices do not necessarily reflect inflation.
  2. New products and services: New products and services that improve people's lives are often not accounted for in the CPI.

docs.title: Consequences
docs.text:
• Real wage statistics are biased downward.
  • The upward bias of the CPI averages around 1% or more per year, which means:
    • When the CPI shows 3% inflation per year, it is really more like 2% inflation per year.
    • Over a period of 25 years, this difference can result in an average American income per person being under-estimated by almost $9,000 per year.

docs.title: Impact
docs.text:
• An American family of three has a real income of more than $25,000 per year higher than the official statistics on real wages would indicate.
  • Alarms about declining real wages over time are often exaggerated and misleading.

docs.title: Measuring Standard of Living: Challenges and Complications
Statistical Artifacts vs. Actual Facts
docs.text:
• Declining real wages do not necessarily mean a decrease in standard of living.
  • During periods of declining real wages, average American consumption increased dramatically, and net worth more than doubled.

docs.title: Measuring Compensation and Benefits
docs.text:
• More compensation takes the form of job-related benefits rather than direct wages.
  • Total compensation rose during periods of declining real wages due to increases in benefits.

docs.title: International Comparisons: Challenges and Limitations
docs.text:
• Comparing outputs between countries with different economies and products is challenging.
  • Qualitative differences in output make comparisons difficult, similar to comparing apples and oranges or cars and sugar.
  • Examples:
    • Caribbean nation's output of tropical crops vs. Scandinavian country's industrial products.
    • Soviet Union's poor-quality products (e.g., cameras and cars) vs. other countries' high-quality products.

docs.title: Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Measuring standard of living is complex due to various factors, including statistical artifacts and qualitative differences in output.
  • International comparisons require careful consideration of these challenges to ensure accurate conclusions.

docs.title: Statistical Comparisons of Economic Output
docs.text:
• Quantitative comparisons of economic output can be misleading due to differences in technology and industry structure
  • Example: India's watch production was mostly mechanical watches, while the rest of the world had electronic watches, making international comparisons inaccurate

docs.title: Qualitative Improvements in Economic Output
docs.text:
• Lifting government restrictions on the economy in late 20th century led to dramatic qualitative improvements in India's industries (watches, cars, TV sets, telephone service)
  • These improvements included rapid technological advances and reduced waiting times for goods and services

docs.title: Statistical Comparisons of Incomes
docs.text:
• Age differences between nations affect statistical comparisons of incomes
  • Example: Median ages in Nigeria, Afghanistan, and Tanzania are under 20, while Japan, Italy, and Germany have median ages over 40
  • Such age gaps can lead to inaccurate conclusions about economic differences between nations

docs.title: International Differences in Income: A Misleading Picture
The Issue with International Comparisons
docs.text: The real significance of some international differences in income may be overstated. This is because national statistics count expensive medications, treatments, and care for older populations as part of a country's output.

docs.title: The Role of Nature in Providing Free Services
docs.text:
Nature provides free services that are costly to replicate for older populations. For example:

  • Tropical countries get free heat for growing pineapples and bananas, while other countries would incur huge heating bills.
  • Young people require fewer expensive medications and treatments compared to older populations.

docs.title: Overstating Economic Well-being
docs.text: Statistics on real income per capita overstate the difference in economic well-being between older people in Western nations and younger people in non-Western nations.

docs.title: A More Accurate Picture
docs.text: If it were possible to remove the additional costs associated with caring for an older population (e.g., wheelchairs, pacemakers, nursing homes) from national statistics, international comparisons of real income would more accurately reflect actual levels of economic well-being.

docs.title: The Value of Youth
docs.text: An elderly person in a wheelchair would gladly trade places with a young person who doesn't need one. This highlights that the value of youth and health cannot be captured by gross international statistical comparisons.

docs.title: Summary Notes
docs.text:
• Prices play a crucial role in allocating resources efficiently, directing supplies to areas where demand is highest.
  • Markets don't imply that earnings remain constant over time or that resource allocation follows an ideal pattern indefinitely.

docs.title: Key Points:
docs.text:
• Prices as Incentives: Prices act as powerful incentives for suppliers to increase or decrease production in response to changing demand.
  • Rationing and Allocation: Prices ration existing supplies and direct them to areas where they are most valued, maximizing efficiency.
  • Self-Interest vs. Altruism: Individuals tend to work harder and make greater sacrifices when driven by self-interest (e.g., earning top dollar) rather than altruistic motivations.

docs.title: Real-World Example:
docs.text: In a region experiencing food shortages, suppliers are incentivized to rush food to the area due to high prices. This leads to a faster response than if government employees were transporting food on a humanitarian mission, as suppliers are driven by self-interest and eager to capitalize on high prices.

docs.title: Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Markets allocate resources efficiently through price mechanisms.
  • Self-interest drives individuals to work harder and make greater sacrifices.
  • Altruistic motivations may lead to slower responses and less efficient allocation of resources.

docs.title: The Problem with Official Exchange Rates
docs.text:
• Official exchange rates can be misleading when comparing the economic output of different countries.
  • These rates do not always reflect the actual purchasing power of a country's currency.

docs.title: Purchasing Power Parity (PPP)
docs.text:
• PPP is a more accurate measure of a country's economic output, as it takes into account what goods and services can be purchased with a given amount of money.
  • PPP can reveal differences in economic output between countries that are not apparent when using official exchange rates.

docs.title: Example: Japan vs. United States
docs.text:
• Some statistics have claimed that Japan has higher per capita income than the US based on official exchange rates.
  • However, when adjusted for PPP, the average American's annual income could buy more goods and services than the average Japanese citizen's income.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: • The problem lies not with understanding basic economics, but with verbal confusion spread by politicians, media, and others using misleading statistics.

docs.title: Challenges in Comparisons
docs.text:
• Official exchange rates may not accurately reflect the standard of living between countries.
  • Statistics based on these rates can be misleading, creating false impressions about relative prosperity.

docs.title: Example: Japan and the United States
docs.text:
• Despite higher average annual income in Japan, Americans have a higher standard of living.
  • Purchasing power per person in Japan is approximately 71% of that in the United States.

docs.title: Complications in Comparing Output
docs.text:
• Different countries may have varying proportions of output sold through markets versus produced by governments.
  • Government-provided goods and services are often valued at production costs, rather than market prices.

docs.title: Implications for Economic Comparisons
docs.text:
• These differences can exaggerate the value of government-provided goods and services.
  • Many of these goods would not cover their production costs if sold in a free market economy.

docs.title: Comparing Economic Output between Countries
docs.text:
• Gross Domestic Product (GDP) statistics provide a reasonable basis for comparing similar countries at the same time, despite limitations.
  • GDP per capita is a more accurate measure of standard of living than total GDP.

docs.title: Limitations of Economic Statistics
docs.text:
• Comparisons between very different countries or time periods are problematic.
  • Statistics should not be taken as precise measures, but rather rough estimates.

docs.title: Relationship between Economic Prosperity and Happiness
docs.text:
• Opinion polls show some correlation between national prosperity and personal satisfaction.
  • However, correlation does not imply causation; other factors such as security and freedom may contribute to both happiness and economic prosperity.

Key Quotes

  • It is better to be roughly right than precisely wrong. - John Maynard Keynes
  • Money cannot buy happiness (old saying)

Key Statistics

  • Norway's GDP per capita in 2009 was more than double that of Italy.

docs.title: Purpose of International Comparison
docs.text:
The validity of national output statistics depends on the purpose of comparison.

  • Total Output: Measures a country's military, humanitarian, or economic power.
  • Standard of Living: Measures a country's average standard of living, taking into account population size.

docs.title: Gross Domestic Product (GDP)
docs.text:
• Measures total output of a country.
  • Can be misleading when comparing countries with vastly different population sizes.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
• In 2009:
    • Top 5 countries by GDP: USA, China, Japan, India, Germany
    • China had the second-highest GDP but not among top 5 in GDP per capita
    • None of the top 5 countries by GDP were among top 5 in GDP per capita

docs.title: Limitations of GDP per Capita
docs.text:
• Small countries with tax havens can attract foreign wealth, skewing their GDP per capita.
  • Examples: Bermuda and other small island nations.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: When comparing national output statistics, it's essential to consider the purpose of comparison and the limitations of each metric.

docs.title: Comparing National Output
docs.text:
• The choice of starting year can greatly affect comparisons of national output over time.
  • The validity of claims about economic growth rates depends on the base year selected.

docs.title: Example: 1960 US Presidential Campaign
docs.text:
• John F. Kennedy's campaign promise to get America moving again economically implied a stagnated growth rate under his opponent's party.
  • However, the actual growth rate varied greatly depending on the starting year:
    • 1.9% since 1945
    • 4.4% since 1958

docs.title: Long-term Average Growth Rate
docs.text: • The long-term average annual rate of growth of the Gross National Product of the United States is about 3% per year.

docs.title: Standard of Living Comparisons
docs.text:
• A higher GDP per capita does not necessarily mean a higher standard of living.
  • Example: Bermuda's GDP per capita is higher than that of the United States, but this does not mean its average permanent resident has a higher standard of living.

docs.title: Dependence on Base Year
docs.text:
• Trends can be misleading depending on the base year chosen
  • Crime in the US: increased from 1960 to present, but decreased from 1990 to present
  • Income inequality: same in 1939 and 1999, but appeared to increase from 1980s onward due to fluctuations
  • Investment returns: 10.5% annual rate of return since 1963, but nearly zero percent rate of return since 1998

docs.title: Interpreting Trends Outside Economics
docs.text:
• Automobile fatality rates: declined after federal government imposed safety regulations, but were already declining for decades before regulations
  • Questionable effectiveness of policies based on continuation of existing trends

docs.title: Limitations of Official Data
docs.text:
• Economic activity off the books in some countries (especially Third World) leads to underestimation of national output
  • Unpaid domestic work (cooking, raising children, cleaning) goes uncounted in all countries

docs.title: Inaccuracy in Economic Activity Measurement
docs.text:
• Economic activity is not always accurately measured due to changes in domestic activities over time and variations between societies.
  • As more women enter the workforce, domestic chores are outsourced to paid services, increasing national output statistics.

docs.title: Impact on National Output Trends
docs.text:
• Statistics reflect both real increases in goods and services produced and increased counting of previously uncounted activities.
  • Shifting economic activities from home to marketplace makes long-term statistics not comparable.

docs.title: Historical Examples
docs.text:
• In the past, families grew and preserved their own food, reducing reliance on market-purchased goods.
  • Alexander Hamilton's 1791 Report on Manufactures noted that four-fifths of American clothing was homemade.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: • Changes in domestic activities over time and between societies affect economic activity measurement, leading to inaccuracies in national output trends.

docs.title: Notes on Economic Statistics and Poverty
Challenges in Measuring Economic Growth
docs.text:
• National output statistics may not accurately reflect real increases in totals over time
  • Differences in recording and underreporting can affect statistical trends
  • Statistical trends can both overstate and understate economic growth

docs.title: The Impact of Poverty on Statistics
docs.text:
• In poor Third World countries, increasing prosperity can be masked by high infant mortality rates and health risks
  • As countries rise economically, more infants and vulnerable individuals survive due to better nutrition and medical care
  • However, this increased survival rate can lead to a higher percentage of the population being classified as poor
  • Statistically, this can understate or even show a decline in average income, despite actual economic growth

docs.title: Key Points to Consider
docs.text:
• Economic statistics should be interpreted with caution, considering both overreporting and underreporting biases
  • Poverty and inequality can affect statistical trends, making it essential to consider the broader context when analyzing economic data.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Every individual in the country has experienced an increase in income compared to the past.
  • The text implies a positive trend of rising incomes over time.

Note: Since the provided text is very short and lacks specific details, these summary notes are brief and general. If more context or information is available, more detailed notes can be provided.

docs.title: Chapter 17: Money and the Banking System
Importance of Money and Banking
docs.text:
• Money and banking play crucial roles in promoting production of goods and services, which affects everyone's standard of living.
  • They are essential for maintaining full employment of people and resources in the economy.

docs.title: Misconceptions about Wealth
docs.text: • Money is not wealth; if it were, governments could easily solve economic problems by simply printing more money.

docs.title: Key Point
docs.text:
• A system established to prevent bank panics ironically led to the most severe banking panic in American history (as noted by Milton Friedman).

Let me know if you'd like me to clarify or expand on any of these points!

docs.title: The Role of Self-Interest in Economic Progress
docs.text:
• Self-interest can drive innovation and progress, even if it appears unattractive or greedy.
  • In the case of food supplies, earlier arrival can be the difference between life and death.

docs.title: The Problem with Government Intervention
docs.text:
• Government-provided aid can often arrive too late to make a difference.
  • Bureaucratic inefficiencies can lead to waste and spoilage.

docs.title: How Markets Adapt to Change
docs.text:
• When demand for certain products declines (e.g., horse-drawn carriages), manufacturers must adapt or shut down.
  • This process may seem unfair to individual producers, but it leads to greater efficiency for the economy as a whole.

docs.title: The Tradeoff Between Efficiency and Fairness
docs.text:
• Creating more fairness among producers could come at the cost of reduced efficiency and lower standard of living for consumers.
  • Is this tradeoff worth making?

docs.title: The Importance of a Well-Designed Monetary System
docs.text:
• A well-designed monetary system facilitates the production and distribution of wealth.
  • The banking system plays a vital role in this process.

docs.title: The Scale of the Banking System
docs.text:
• American banks had $14 trillion in assets in 2012.
  • To put this number into perspective, a trillion seconds ago, no one on this planet could read or write.

docs.title: The History of Money and Trade
docs.text:
• Economies in the distant past functioned without money.
  • People bartered their products and labor with one another.
  • Barter is awkward and limited to small, uncomplicated economies.

docs.title: Challenges of Bartering
docs.text:
• Difficult to find someone who wants what you have and has what you want.
  • Example: trading a chair for apples is not likely to be a fair or desirable exchange.

docs.title: Summary Notes
docs.text:
The Emergence of Money

  • The concept of money arose from the need for a common medium of exchange to facilitate trade.
  • Initially, items like chairs and apples were used for bartering, but this system had limitations.

The Role of Intermediary Means of Exchange

  • A third item that can be subdivided into small units can serve as an intermediary means of exchange, enabling more trades to take place.
  • This intermediary means of exchange eventually becomes money.

Historical Examples of Unconventional Currencies

  • Various societies have used different items as money, including:
    • Sea shells
    • Silver and gold
    • Special pieces of paper (printed by governments)
    • Warehouse receipts for tobacco (in colonial America)
    • Bottles and cases of gin (in British West Africa)
    • Cigarettes (in a prisoner-of-war camp during World War II)
    • Goods like flour, grain, and salt (in the early Soviet Union)
    • Doughnut-shaped rocks (in part of Micronesia)

Key Takeaways

  • The concept of money is not inherent to any particular item, but rather emerges from its use as a medium of exchange.
  • Various items can serve as money, depending on what societies agree upon.

docs.title: Summary Notes
docs.text:
The Function of Money

  • Money facilitates the production of real wealth
  • It is an artifact used to transfer wealth or give people incentives to produce wealth
  • While money is not equivalent to wealth in a national economy, it plays a crucial role in greasing the wheels of production

Characteristics of Money

  • What makes something money is that people accept it as payment for goods and services
  • Ownership of money can change instantaneously without physical movement of currency or coins
  • Examples of primitive systems of money include rocks, which circulate through ownership rather than physical movement

Consequences of a Broken Monetary System

  • When a monetary system breaks down, people resort to barter, which is clumsy and inefficient
  • Example: Argentina's monetary system broke down in 2002, leading to a decline in economic activity and the rise of bartering clubs called trueque

Key Points

  • Money is not wealth, but rather an artifact used to facilitate its production and exchange
  • The role of money may seem inconsequential, but it plays a crucial function in lubricating the wheels of production
  • A broken monetary system can have severe consequences for economic activity.

docs.title: Summary of Bartering and Monetary Systems
Key Points
docs.text:
• In Argentina, a bartering system was used to exchange goods and services due to a breakdown in the monetary system.
  • A local baker traded 220 pounds of bread for half a ton of firewood with a club.
  • Affluent neighborhoods had trueque where high-end goods were exchanged.
  • Bartering systems have been used in other countries during times of economic crisis, such as during the Great Depression in the US.

docs.title: The Limitations of Money
docs.text:
• Money is not wealth itself, but an absence of a well-functioning monetary system can cause losses of real wealth.
  • When transactions are reduced to barter, it can lead to inefficiencies and difficulties in trade.
  • There have been instances where people refused to accept money due to its perceived worthlessness.

docs.title: Historical Examples
docs.text:
• In France during the 1790s, the government passed a law making it punishable by death to refuse to sell goods for money.
  • During the Great Depression, there were an estimated 150 barter and/or scrip systems in operation in the US.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: • The acceptance of money is not guaranteed and can be influenced by various factors such as economic conditions and government policies.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: To avoid economic malfunctions, it's essential to understand money functions. Two significant malfunctions are inflation and deflation.

docs.title: Inflation
docs.text:
• Definition: A general rise in prices.
  • Cause: An increase in demand without a corresponding increase in output, leading to a shortage of goods and services.
  • Effect: Prices rise as people bid against each other or sellers raise their prices due to increased demand.

Key Points

  • The relationship between the total amount of money and the general price level has been observed for centuries.
  • An increase in the money supply leads to higher prices, unless there is a corresponding increase in goods and services.

Historical Examples

  • Alexander the Great's spending of captured treasures led to rising prices in Greece.
  • The Spanish removal of gold from their colonies resulted in rising price levels across Europe.

docs.title: Money and its Value
docs.text:
• The value of money is not inherent, but rather a social construct.
  • Complications arise when considering intrinsic value or thinking that money is backed up by something else.

docs.title: History of Gold as Money
docs.text:
• Gold has been used as money throughout history due to its convenience and portability.
  • It was often used in coins, nuggets, bars, or other forms for large purchases.
  • Paper money printed by governments, redeemable in gold, became a more convenient alternative.

docs.title: Problems with Government-Created Money
docs.text:
• Governments face the temptation to create more money and spend it, leading to inflation and economic problems.
  • This has occurred repeatedly throughout history among ancient kings and modern politicians.

docs.title: Alternative Forms of Money
docs.text: • Many countries have preferred using inherently limited materials like gold, silver, or others as money to prevent government over-expansion of the money supply.

docs.title: Summary Notes
docs.text:
Money Supply and Inflation

  • Gold has been considered ideal for limiting money supply to prevent inflation
  • Paper money was once convertible into gold, but this is no longer the case
  • The value of paper money is not transferred from gold, but rather limited by the amount of gold available

History of the American Dollar

  • The dollar was once redeemable in gold on demand, but this ended in 1933
  • Since then, the US has had paper money with supply limited only by government officials' discretion

Dangers of Unchecked Government Power

  • Many economists have pointed out the dangers of unchecked government power to print money
  • John Maynard Keynes wrote that governments can confiscate citizens' wealth through inflation
  • Example: In 1960, a dollar could buy six times more than it can today, resulting in a silent theft of value from savers

Consequences of Inflation

  • Inflation has cumulative effects, leading to significant losses in purchasing power over time
  • Sobering as US inflation may be, it pales in comparison to levels reached in some other countries.

docs.title: Inflation
docs.text:
• Double-digit inflation in the United States can create political alarms
  • Some countries in Latin America and Eastern Europe have experienced four-digit annual inflation rates

docs.title: Alternative Forms of Money
docs.text:
• Credit cards, debit cards, and checks function similarly to official government-issued money
  • Mere promises from highly trusted individuals or organizations can also serve as money
  • Examples include:
    • IOUs from reliable merchants
    • Private banknotes (e.g. Bank of North America in the 1780s)

docs.title: Aggregate Demand
docs.text:
• Created not only by government-issued money but also by credits from various sources
  • Liquidation of credits reduces aggregate demand, similar to a contraction in the official money supply

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Money is whatever is accepted as payment for goods and services
  • Various forms of credit can function as money
  • Aggregate demand is influenced by both government-issued money and private credits

docs.title: Preference for Foreign Currencies
docs.text:
• In some cases, people prefer to use foreign currencies over their own national currency.
  • Examples:
    • Japan preferred Chinese money in the late 10th century.
    • Bolivia used US dollars in savings accounts during hyperinflation in 1985.
    • South Africa's rand replaced Zimbabwe's dollar as the currency of choice in 2007.

docs.title: Gold as a Preferred Store of Value
docs.text:
• Gold is often preferred over national currencies, despite earning no interest.
  • The price of gold fluctuates based on:
    • Demand for jewelry and industrial uses (about 80% of demand).
    • Expectations about inflation and the value of official currencies.
  • During times of crisis, people may dump their currency holdings and bid up the price of gold as a more reliable store of wealth.

docs.title: Historical Examples
docs.text:
• During the American Civil War, Southerners used US currency instead of Confederate currency.
  • Major political or military crises can cause the price of gold to surge as people seek a safe-haven asset.

docs.title: Factors Affecting Gold Prices
docs.text:
• Inflation and economic instability lead to increased demand for gold as a shelter from wealth confiscation.
  • Periods of prosperity with low inflation cause the demand for gold to fall, leading to decreased prices.

docs.title: Historical Examples
docs.text:
• 1979: Sharpest rate of increase in gold price (135%) due to high inflation.
  • 1981: Sharpest fall in gold price (32%) following economic stability.
  • Late 1990s: Gold price fell from $800/ounce to $250/ounce during a period of steady growth and low inflation.
  • Early 21st century: Record-breaking federal deficits and European economic problems led to a surge in gold prices over $1,000/ounce.

docs.title: Underlying Fear
docs.text: • The unspoken fear behind the demand for gold is inflation, driven by governments' tendency to resort to inflation as a means of increasing wealth without raising taxes.

docs.title: Economic Interconnectedness
docs.text:
• We are all dependent on others for our lives, including innumerable strangers who produce goods and services.
  • Economic activities among people are tied together through prices.

docs.title: Crucial Role of Prices
docs.text:
• Prices induce others to create goods and services we need.
  • Economic incentives are essential for this purpose.

docs.title: Misconceptions about Unmet Needs
docs.text:
• Politicians, journalists, and academicians often point out unmet needs in society that should be addressed by government programs.
  • Economics is the study of using scarce resources, which have alternative uses.

docs.title: Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Prices play a crucial role in connecting economic activities among people.
  • We are all interdependent on others for our lives.
  • Economic incentives are necessary to induce others to create goods and services we need.

docs.title: Summary Notes
docs.text:
Consequences of Higher Taxes

  • Public reaction can range from dissatisfaction to armed revolt (e.g., American War of Independence)
  • Adverse economic reactions:
    • Abandonment of certain economic activities due to low net rate of return after taxes
    • Example: Decline of agriculture in the Roman Empire, leading to increased dependence on government support

Government Response to Taxation Challenges

  • Inflation as an alternative to raising tax rates
  • Governments have used inflation for thousands of years to avoid political dangers associated with taxation

docs.title: Key Quote
docs.text: • There is no record of a prolonged war or great social upheaval which has not been accompanied by change in the legal tender... - John Maynard Keynes

docs.title: Causes of Inflation
docs.text:
• War efforts can lead to inflation when a government creates more money to buy war materials, reducing the availability of civilian goods.
  • Governments may also cause inflation by spending on luxurious projects or showy initiatives.

docs.title: Effects of Inflation
docs.text:
• Reduces the purchasing power of saved money
  • Quietly transfers wealth from individuals to the government that issues new money
  • Acts as a broad-based tax, affecting everyone who has money

docs.title: Characteristics of Inflation
docs.text:
• Hidden tax: not explicitly announced by the government
  • Broad-based tax: affects people across all income ranges

docs.title: Government's Role in Inflation
docs.text:
• Governments may choose to create more money instead of raising taxes to pay for their expenses.
  • This can lead to inflation, which is a hidden and broad-based tax on individuals.

docs.title: How Inflation Affects Different Income Groups
docs.text:
• The rich can escape some of the effects of inflation by investing in assets that rise in value with inflation, such as stocks and real estate.
  • People in lower income brackets may not be able to escape the effects of inflation.

docs.title: Creating More Money Throughout History
docs.text:
• In the past, governments created more money by reducing the amount of precious metal in coins.
  • This allowed them to issue more money from a given supply of gold or silver.
  • The purchasing power of the new coins declined as they became more abundant.

docs.title: Modern Methods of Increasing the Money Supply
docs.text:
• Governments with central banks can increase the quantity of money using more sophisticated methods.
  • However, the net result is still the same: an increase in the amount of money without a corresponding increase in real goods leads to inflation.

docs.title: The Relationship Between Output and Inflation
docs.text:
• When output increases without a corresponding increase in the money supply, prices tend to decline.
  • Example: Britain's industrial revolution in the 19th century saw a decrease in prices due to increased output without a corresponding increase in the money supply.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
• Doubling the money supply while keeping the amount of goods constant can more than double the price level due to increased circulation speed when people lose confidence in the currency's value.
  • Historical examples include:
    • Russia (1998): drastic decline in ruble value led to rapid spending and inflation.
    • Russia (1917-1921): massive increase in currency issue led to thousands of times higher price levels.
    • Soviet Union (1991): ruble devaluation made it nearly worthless, used for wallpaper and toilet paper.
    • Germany (1920s): hyperinflation rendered life savings worthless, with 4 trillion marks equaling one dollar.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Money circulation speed: increased speed can lead to higher price levels, similar to having more money in circulation.
  • Runaway inflation: simultaneous increase in money supply and circulation speed can cause extreme inflation.
  • Loss of confidence: when people lose faith in a currency's value, they may spend it quickly, leading to inflation.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
• Russia (1998): Moscow correspondent reported citizens spending rubles as fast as possible due to declining value.
  • Germany (1920s): 40 marks were worth one dollar in July 1920, but by November 1923, it took over 4 trillion marks to equal one dollar.

docs.title: Page 564
docs.text: Notes on Hyperinflation and Economic Chaos

docs.title: Effects of Runaway Inflation
docs.text:
• Leads to economic chaos and disillusionment
  • Sets the stage for extreme political movements, e.g. rise of Adolf Hitler and the Nazis
  • Creates starving billionaires with vast amounts of worthless money

docs.title: Measuring Inflation
docs.text:
• Consumer Price Index (CPI) is an approximation of inflation rates
  • CPI measures changes in prices of different goods and services
  • Example: US consumer prices rose 3.4% in March 2006, but individual price changes ranged from -1.2% to +17.3%

docs.title: Consequences of Hyperinflation
docs.text:
• Reduces purchasing power and consumption
  • Lowers production and demand for labor
  • Can bring an economy to a halt
  • Example: Latin America's real output fell in 1990 due to inflation rates peaking at around 600%

docs.title: Deflation vs. Inflation
docs.text:
• Both can have devastating effects on the economy
  • Deflation leads to reduced consumption, production, and employment
  • Hyperinflation can similarly bring an economy to a halt

docs.title: Definition and Effects
docs.text:
• Deflation occurs when there is a sustained decrease in the general price level of goods and services.
  • It can have devastating effects on economies, particularly for debtors.

docs.title: 1873-1896: Britain and United States
docs.text:
• Prices declined by 22% in Britain and 32% in the United States.
  • The gold standard was in place, but output growth outpaced the increase in gold supply.
  • Debts remained constant in money terms, making mortgages and other debts more burdensome in real purchasing power.

docs.title: 1929-1933: United States
docs.text:
• Money supply declined by one-third, leading to a sharp decrease in prices.
  • Americans were unable to purchase as many goods and services at old prices.

docs.title: Impact on Specific Groups
docs.text: • Farmers: Agricultural produce prices declined sharply, while input costs did not decline as much. This led to increased burden of mortgages and other farm debts.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: Deflation can have severe consequences for economies, particularly for debtors and specific industries like agriculture. Understanding the causes and effects of deflation is crucial for policymakers to mitigate its impact.

docs.title: The Effects of Deflation in the 1930s
Introduction
docs.text:
• The Sears catalog for 1931 showed lower prices compared to a decade earlier
  • However, some prices were fixed due to legal contracts, such as mortgages and leases

docs.title: Impact on Homeowners and Businesses
docs.text:
• Mortgages with fixed monthly payments became harder to pay as the money supply contracted
  • Homeowners, farmers, and businesses lost their properties due to inability to pay
  • Leases also became difficult to afford, leading to similar problems for renters

docs.title: Credit and Debt
docs.text:
• Debts incurred during a time of larger money supply became harder to pay off
  • Businesses and individuals struggled with debts as the economy contracted

docs.title: Impact on Workers and Government Employees
docs.text:
• Those with contracts specifying wages or salaries saw an increase in real purchasing power
  • However, this led to job losses for many workers, including unionized workers and government employees
  • Professional baseball players were also affected by contractually specified salaries

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
• Deflation had far-reaching consequences for individuals and businesses
  • While some groups benefitted from increased purchasing power, many others lost their jobs or properties due to inability to pay fixed debts.

docs.title: The Great Depression and Deflation
docs.text:
Key Points

  • During the Great Depression, many people were unable to pay their debts, leading to bank failures (over 9,000 banks suspended operations between 1930-1933)
  • Deflation made it worse as people held onto money longer, reducing demand for goods and services
  • This led to mass unemployment due to reduced demand for labor

Causes of Deflation

  • People spending less due to economic uncertainty
  • Reduced money circulation during the downturn in the economy (1929-1932)
  • Money circulated more slowly, further reducing demand for goods and services

Potential Solution

  • Increasing the money supply through the Federal Reserve System could have brought prices back up
  • Theoretical possibility of government intervention to stimulate the economy

Important Dates

  • 1929: Start of the Great Depression
  • 1930-1933: Over 9,000 banks suspended operations
  • Woodrow Wilson administration (early 20th century): Establishment of the Federal Reserve System

docs.title: Government Control of Credit System
docs.text:
• A public board of government officials is proposed to control the credit system to avoid influence from bankers and special interests.
  • However, this does not guarantee that decisions will be made in the best interest of the economy.

docs.title: Limitations of Government Decision-Making
docs.text:
• Government officials may have political interests that influence their decisions.
  • Lack of personal financial interest does not mean decisions are necessarily competent.
  • Unlike private market decision-makers, government officials face no automatic correction for poor decisions.

docs.title: Historical Example: The Great Depression
docs.text:
• Conservative and liberal economists agree that the Federal Reserve System's monetary policies during the 1930s were confused and counterproductive.
  • Examples of poor decision-making include:
    • Raising interest rates in 1931, despite a severe economic downturn.
    • Failing to address massive unemployment and business failures.

docs.title: Criticisms from Notable Economists
docs.text:
• Milton Friedman: Federal Reserve officials during the Great Depression were inept.
  • John Kenneth Galbraith: The group showed startling incompetence.

docs.title: Summary Notes
docs.text:
The Great Depression and Economic Policy

  • Higher interest rates during the Great Depression reduced credit and aggregate demand, exacerbating the economic downturn.
  • Presidents Herbert Hoover (Republican) and Franklin D. Roosevelt (Democrat) were not economically sophisticated and thought that reducing wage rates would worsen the depression.

docs.title: Wage Rates and Employment
docs.text:
• Maintaining wage rates in money terms was intended to preserve purchasing power and prevent further declines in sales, output, and employment.
  • However, this policy only worked if people kept their jobs, and higher wage rates under deflation meant lower employment.
  • Higher real wage rates did not translate into higher aggregate earnings for labor, providing no basis for increased aggregate demand.

docs.title: Critique of Wage Rate Policy
docs.text:
• Joseph A. Schumpeter, a leading economist of the era, argued that resistance to downward adjustments in money wages made the Great Depression worse.
  • Schumpeter believed that the depression was caused by other factors and was intensified by inflexible wage rates.

docs.title: Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Economic policy during the Great Depression was often misguided and exacerbated the crisis.
  • Wage rate policies can have unintended consequences, such as reducing employment and aggregate demand.

docs.title: Unmet Needs and Resource Allocation
docs.text:
• Unmet needs will always exist due to limited resources with alternative uses.
  • Meeting one unmet need can lead to others being even more unfulfilled.

docs.title: The Example of Parking Spaces
docs.text:
• Building cities with abundant parking spaces is economically and technologically possible but comes at a high cost.
  • The cost of creating vast new underground or above-ground parking garages would be astronomical.

docs.title: Opportunity Costs
docs.text:
• Meeting the unmet need for parking spaces requires giving up other things, such as:
    • Fewer hospitals
    • Less protection
    • Fewer fire departments
    • Public libraries
  • Individuals may differ on what is worth sacrificing to have more of something else.

docs.title: Key Takeaway
docs.text: • Demonstrating an unmet need is not sufficient to justify meeting it when resources are scarce and have alternative uses.

docs.title: Economic Misconceptions During the Great Depression
docs.text:
Key Points

  • Both Presidents Hoover and Roosevelt failed to understand basic economic principles during the Great Depression.
  • Columnist Walter Lippmann noted in 1934 that businesses couldn't sell goods or services at pre-depression prices, leading to unemployment if they insisted on pre-depression wages.

docs.title: Misconceptions about Wages and Prices
docs.text:
• Politicians, not workers, were pushing for pre-depression wages, despite the economic reality.
  • The Hoover administration applied flawed reasoning to agriculture, trying to prop up farm product prices through government support.
  • President Roosevelt later institutionalized this policy, leading to mass destruction of food during a time of widespread hunger.

docs.title: Global Economic Misconceptions
docs.text: • John Maynard Keynes noted in 1931 that economic misconceptions were not limited to the United States, but were also present in other countries.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: Economic misconceptions were widespread and bipartisan during the Great Depression, leading to flawed policies with devastating consequences.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• The British government's monetary policies may not withstand rational discussion.
  • Monetary policy is not just about what the government can do, but also about what it is likely to do, which can sometimes make the situation worse.

docs.title: Deflation: Causes and Effects
docs.text:
• Deflation occurs when the production of goods and services grows faster than the gold supply, leading to a decline in prices.
  • During the heyday of the gold standard (19th-20th centuries), prices tended to decline as the money supply grew slower than the supply of goods and services.
  • Deflation increases the purchasing power of money, making:
    • Mortgages, leases, contracts, and other legal obligations payable in money grow in real value.
    • Debtors owe more in real purchasing power than they agreed to pay when borrowing money.

docs.title: Problems Created by Deflation
docs.text: • Different people's incomes are affected differently by price changes, leading to additional problems.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
• Deflation can become a serious problem even outside of national and international catastrophes.
  • Monetary policy must consider not only what the government can do but also what it is likely to do, as well as the potential effects of deflation on the economy.

docs.title: Economic Hardship for Farmers (1892-1896)
docs.text:
• Prices of goods sold by farmers fell faster than prices of goods they bought.
  • Wheat price dropped from $1/bushel to below 50 cents/bushel in the winter of 1895-1896.

docs.title: Mortgage Payments and Deflation
docs.text:
• Mortgage payments remained the same in money terms but increased in real terms due to deflation.
  • Farmers struggled to pay mortgages with reduced incomes (half or less than when mortgages were taken out).

docs.title: William Jennings Bryan's Campaign (1896)
docs.text:
• Ran for presidency on a platform to end the gold standard.
  • Famous speech: You shall not crucify mankind upon a cross of gold.
  • Narrowly defeated by William McKinley.

docs.title: Discovery of New Gold Deposits ( late 1800s)
docs.text:
• New gold deposits found in South Africa, Australia, and Alaska led to increased prices for the first time in twenty years.
  • Prices of farm produce rose rapidly due to increased gold supply.

docs.title: Notes on the Gold Standard and Banking System
The Gold Standard
docs.text:
• The gold standard restricts politicians' ability to manipulate the money supply, keeping inflation and deflation within narrower limits.
  • However, it does not prevent either inflation or deflation entirely.
  • The growth of output faster than the growth of the supply can cause a general fall in the average price level.

docs.title: Effects of the Gold Standard
docs.text:
• More countries adopted the gold standard at the end of the 19th and beginning of the 20th centuries.
  • Discoveries of large gold deposits can cause inflationary levels to rise.

docs.title: The Banking System
docs.text:
• Banks exist due to economies of scale in guarding money.
  • Transferring money to banks allows individuals and enterprises to have their money guarded at lower costs than if they were to guard it themselves.
  • This reduces the incentive for criminals to hold up businesses and homes.

docs.title: Storage and Security
docs.text:
• Banks can invest in security measures such as vaults, guards, and armored cars to protect money and valuables.
  • In the US, Federal Reserve Banks store money and gold for private banks and the government, with highly effective security systems that have never been breached.

docs.title: Economies of Scale
docs.text:
• Banks can guard wealth at a lower cost per unit than private businesses or homes due to economies of scale.
  • The Federal Reserve Banks can also guard wealth at a lower cost per unit than private banks.

docs.title: Active Role in the Economy
docs.text:
• Banks play an active role in the economy beyond just storing money.
  • They help businesses manage unpredictable incomes and steady expenses, such as employee salaries and utility bills.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Banks provide secure storage for valuables.
  • Economies of scale enable banks to guard wealth at a lower cost.
  • The Federal Reserve Banks have never been robbed due to their effective security systems.
  • Banks play a crucial role in helping businesses manage finances.

docs.title: Role of Commercial Banks in Supplying Businesses with Money
docs.text:
• Commercial banks provide money to businesses when they don't have enough to meet their obligations.
  • This money must come from later profits.

docs.title: Lines of Credit
docs.text:
• Instead of applying for separate loans, businesses can be granted a line of credit for a given sum of money.
  • Businesses use up to that amount as needed and repay it when profits come in, replenishing the fund behind the line of credit.

docs.title: Economies of Scale
docs.text:
• Commercial banks maintain central funds from which individual businesses can draw money as needed.
  • This provides economies of scale and risk-pooling benefits for both the banks and their customers.
  • Customers save time and money by not having to apply for separate loans each time they need cash.

docs.title: Benefits of Shifting Risks
docs.text:
• Commercial banks charge interest for their services, but their costs are lower than those of their customers due to economies of scale and risk-pooling.
  • Both the banks and their customers benefit financially from shifting risks to where the costs are lower.

docs.title: Summary Notes
docs.text:
Lower Production Costs and Prices

  • Businesses achieve lower production costs through large-scale operations, requiring significant labor, machinery, electricity, and resources.
  • These costs are translated into lower prices for consumers.

Ownership of Giant Corporations

  • Most giant corporations are not owned by a few rich individuals.
  • Instead, they draw on money from vast numbers of people with modest sums, aggregated and transferred through financial intermediaries like banks, insurance companies, mutual funds, and pension funds.

Individual Investment

  • Individuals can transfer their own money directly to businesses by buying stocks and bonds, but this requires doing their own risk assessments.
  • Alternatively, individuals can transfer their money through financial intermediaries who evaluate investment risks and earnings prospects on their behalf.

Evaluation of Financial Institutions

  • Individual owners of money transferred through financial institutions evaluate the riskiness and earnings prospects of the financial institutions themselves.
  • This includes decisions about whether to invest in insured savings accounts, pension plans, mutual funds, or other investment vehicles.

Role of Banks

  • Banks finance consumer purchases by paying for credit purchases and later reimbursed by the credit card holder.

docs.title: Role in Enabling Spending
docs.text:
• Financial intermediaries enable millions of people to spend money that belongs to others
  • This facilitates investments in businesses and consumer purchases
  • Example: Visa forms a network with 14,800 banks and financial institutions to provide money for purchases made by over 100 million credit card users

docs.title: Importance to the Economy
docs.text:
• Financial intermediaries play a crucial role in enabling strangers to turn vast sums of money over to other strangers
  • Countries without sufficient knowledgeable, experienced, and trustworthy intermediaries often struggle with poverty despite natural resources
  • Financial intermediaries facilitate turning natural resources into goods, services, homes, and businesses, creating wealth

docs.title: Money as a Means of Transfer
docs.text:
• Money itself is not wealth, but it facilitates the production and transfer of wealth
  • Real wealth (tangible things) can be redirected toward others through banks and financial institutions using money as the means of transfer

Key Takeaways

  • Financial intermediaries play a vital role in enabling spending and investments
  • They facilitate turning natural resources into goods, services, homes, and businesses, creating wealth
  • Money serves as an important means of transferring wealth.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The banking system plays a crucial role in affecting the total demand in the economy as a whole by creating credits that add to the money supply through fractional reserve banking.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Fractional Reserve Banking: A practice where banks keep only a fraction of deposits in reserve and lend out the rest, thereby increasing the money supply.
  • Origins of Fractional Reserve Banking: Goldsmiths stored gold for others and issued receipts, which eventually became a medium of exchange. They then lent out some of this gold, keeping only a fraction in reserve.
  • Economies of Scale: Storing gold in vaults or strongholds was more cost-effective than individual storage facilities.
  • Impact on Demand: The banking system's creation of credits increases the total demand for goods and services in the economy.

docs.title: Importance of Banking Transactions
docs.text:
• Banking transactions do not simply transfer cash but affect the overall demand in the economy.
  • Important for other purposes, such as facilitating trade and investment.

docs.title: Distinction from Other Financial Intermediaries
docs.text: • The banking system's unique role is its ability to create credits that add to the money supply.

docs.title: The Emergence of Modern Banking
docs.text:
Key Features

  • Fractional Reserve Banking: Goldsmiths held only a fraction of the reserves needed to cover deposits, lending out the rest to earn interest.
  • Money Supply Expansion: The banking system adds to the total money supply by creating new credits and loans.

How it Works

  1. Goldsmiths' Receipts: Goldsmiths issued receipts for gold stored with them, which circulated as if they were money.
  2. Lending and Interest: Goldsmiths lent out two-thirds of the gold held in reserve, earning interest on these loans.
  3. Money Supply Growth: As receipts and loans circulated simultaneously, the goldsmith effectively added to the total money supply.

Modern Banking Parallels

  • Deposit Accounts: Banks lend most of the deposited funds to other people, earning interest on those loans.
  • Interest Sharing: Banks share some of this interest with depositors by paying interest on their bank accounts.
  • Money Supply Expansion (again): As depositors write checks on their accounts while part of the money is also circulating as loans, the banking system adds to the national money supply.

Rounds of Expansion

  • Re-deposited Credits: Some bank credits are re-deposited in other banks, leading to additional rounds of expansion of the money supply.

docs.title: Notes on Parking Spaces and Government Expenditures
Key Points
docs.text:
• Restricting or forbidding private automobiles in cities might seem cheaper in terms of government expenditures.
  • However, this approach would require weighing the savings against the vast private expenditures on car ownership, maintenance, and parking.
  • Costs are not just government expenditures, but also foregone opportunities.

docs.title: The Problem with Simplistic Solutions
docs.text:
• Forcing people to give up opportunities they value is a significant cost that may outweigh any potential savings.
  • The issue of parking spaces in cities is a classic example of a trade-off, where there is no clear solution.

docs.title: Trade-Offs and Unmet Needs
docs.text:
• In a world with scarce resources and alternative uses, decisions involve trade-offs rather than solutions.
  • Whatever decision is made will still leave unmet needs.
  • Responding to political rhetoric about unmet needs can lead to arbitrary resource allocation.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: • The discussion around parking spaces highlights the importance of considering all costs and benefits when making decisions about resource allocation.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The banking system allows for a larger amount of bank credits to exist than the actual hard cash issued by the government. This is made possible through fractional reserve banking.

docs.title: How it Works
docs.text:
• When a bank receives checks from its depositors that were written by people with accounts in another bank, it doesn't ask for the full amount.
  • Instead, the banks balance out the checks against each other, settling only the difference.
  • This means that only a fraction of the total amount of checks needs to be settled in cash.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
• Acme Bank receives $1 million worth of checks from its depositors that were written by people with accounts in Zebra Bank.
  • However, Acme Bank's own depositors had written $1.2 million worth of checks to businesses and individuals who deposited them in Zebra Bank.
  • The banks settle only the difference of $200,000.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Banks can keep a fraction of their deposits in cash because all checks require only a fraction of the total amount to settle differences between banks.
  • A relatively small amount of hard cash allows for a much larger amount of credits created by the banking system to function as money in the economy.
  • Fractional reserve banking works because depositors don't want their money in cash at the same time.

docs.title: Normal Conditions vs. Crisis Situations
docs.text:
• In normal times, banks are generally stable
  • However, during crisis situations (e.g., bank robbery), depositors may fear they won't get their money back, leading to a run on the bank

docs.title: Consequences of Bank Run
docs.text:
• If many depositors ask for their money at once, the bank may not have enough cash reserves to meet demand
  • This can lead to the bank running out of money and collapsing, even if it has sufficient assets to cover its liabilities

docs.title: Asset Liquidity Matters
docs.text:
• Assets that cannot be quickly sold or turned into cash are considered illiquid (e.g., buildings, 30-year mortgages)
  • Banks with a high proportion of illiquid assets may struggle to meet depositor demands during a crisis situation

Key Takeaways

  • Bank stability depends on the liquidity of its assets
  • Crisis situations can reveal underlying vulnerabilities in bank stability
  • Deposit insurance and other regulatory measures aim to mitigate these risks

docs.title: What is Liquidity?
docs.text:
• Liquidity refers to the degree to which an asset can be converted to money without losing its value.
  • Examples of liquid assets include American Express traveler's checks, which can be exchanged for cash at their face value.

docs.title: Consequences of Illiquidity in Banking System
docs.text:
• If a bank's assets cannot be liquidated quickly, it may collapse if faced with a run on the bank.
  • This can lead to:
    • Depositors losing their savings
    • A decline in the nation's total demand for goods and services

docs.title: The Great Depression Example
docs.text:
• During the 1930s, thousands of banks in the US collapsed, leading to a contraction of one-third in the country's monetary demand.
  • This was caused by the disappearance of credit created by the banking system.

docs.title: Preventing Future Catastrophes
docs.text:
• The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) was created to guarantee reimbursement for depositors who lose money due to bank failures.
  • This aims to prevent a repetition of the Great Depression.

docs.title: Bank Failures and Deposit Insurance
docs.text:
• The collapse of an insured bank no longer triggers a run on banks, reducing the likelihood of a sudden reduction in the nation's money supply.
  • The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) acts as a firewall to prevent bank failures from spreading.

docs.title: The Federal Reserve System
docs.text:
• A central bank run by the government to control private banks.
  • Has the power to set reserve requirements for banks, influencing lending and credit creation.
  • Lends money to banks at an interest rate that indirectly controls the interest rates charged to the general public.
  • Controls the total amount of money and credit in the economy, influencing aggregate demand.

docs.title: Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• The Federal Reserve System has significant leverage over the economy through its control of interest rates and reserve requirements.
  • Public statements by the Chairman of the Federal Reserve Board are closely watched for clues about future monetary policy decisions.

docs.title: Federal Reserve Board Chairman's Statements: A Delicate Matter
docs.text:
• Impact on Financial Markets: The chairman's statements can significantly impact financial markets, causing stock prices to plummet or soar.
  • Consequences of Misinterpretation: A misconstrued statement can lead to drastic repercussions, affecting investors and financial markets worldwide.

docs.title: The Chairman's Communication Style
docs.text:
• Highly Guarded and Delphic Terms: To avoid misinterpretation, Federal Reserve Board chairmen use carefully crafted language that often leaves listeners puzzled.
  • Examples of Cryptic Statements: Alan Greenspan's statements were notoriously difficult to decipher, with Wall Street and Washington expending significant energy to understand his intentions.

docs.title: Real-Life Examples
docs.text:
• The Sneeze Incident (2004): A news item in the San Francisco Chronicle reported that Alan Greenspan's sneeze was interpreted by traders as a signal to raise interest rates, causing market fluctuations.
  • Omission of Key Phrase: The Federal Reserve chairman's statement omitting a key phrase about keeping interest rates low for a considerable period was seen as a signal to raise prices again.

docs.title: Market Reactions to Federal Reserve Statements
docs.text:
• The Dow Jones average, Nasdaq, and Standard & Poor's Index dropped sharply due to a lack of clarity in statements made by the Federal Reserve Board.
  • This phenomenon was not unique to Alan Greenspan's tenure as chairman.

docs.title: Quantitative Easing under Ben Bernanke
docs.text:
• In 2013, Chairman Ben Bernanke announced that the Federal Reserve might reduce its pace of purchasing U.S. government bonds if the economy improved.
  • The reaction was swift and far-reaching:
    • Japanese stock market lost 21% of its value in less than a month
    • Total losses in global stock markets: $3 trillion (more than France's annual GDP)

docs.title: Assessing the Federal Reserve's Role
docs.text:
• It is essential to distinguish between the Fed's stated goals and actual performance.
  • The Federal Reserve System was established in 1914 to prevent economic consequences like deflation and bank failures.
  • However, the worst deflation and bank failures occurred after its establishment.

Key Takeaways

  • The Federal Reserve's statements can significantly impact financial markets.
  • Quantitative easing can have far-reaching effects on global economies.
  • It is crucial to evaluate government institutions' actual performance rather than just their stated goals.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The stock market crash of 1929 and the Great Depression of the 1930s highlighted the importance of understanding financial crises and banking systems. This summary provides an overview of the key requirements for a successful banking system.

docs.title: Variations in Banking Systems
docs.text: Banking systems vary significantly from one country to another, differing in institutional practices, historical experiences, and general settings. These differences can help illustrate the requirements of a successful banking system and evaluate the effects of particular policies.

docs.title: Requirements for a Banking System
docs.text:
A successful banking system requires more than just taking in deposits and lending money while earning interest. Some key considerations include:

  • Complexity: Banking is a complex business that cannot be underestimated.
  • Free Market Operations: Banks must be able to operate effectively in a free market environment.

docs.title: Challenges in Creating Banking Systems
docs.text:
Some post-Communist nations have faced significant difficulties in creating banking systems that can operate in a free market. Examples include:

  • Albania
  • Czech Republic

These countries' experiences highlight the challenges of establishing effective banking systems, particularly in transitioning economies.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: In conclusion, understanding financial crises and banking systems is crucial for economic stability. A successful banking system requires careful consideration of complexity, free market operations, and institutional practices. The experiences of various countries can provide valuable insights into the requirements of a successful banking system.

docs.title: Economic Development Challenges in Post-Communist Countries
Problem of Lending in Albania
docs.text:
• Banks received deposits but struggled to lend money to private businesses due to concerns about returns on investment and minimizing losses.
  • Weak legal infrastructure hindered lending, with banks afraid to make loans.

docs.title: Consequences for the Economy
docs.text:
• Capital-hungry enterprises were deprived of a source of finance, hindering economic growth.
  • An Albanian bank with 83% of the country's deposits made no loans but instead invested in government securities, earning low returns.

docs.title: Similar Challenges in the Czech Republic
docs.text:
• Lending was more generous, but banks shifted assets into government securities after incurring losses.
  • Government intervention to cover losses was necessary.

docs.title: Long-term Implications
docs.text:
• Time is needed for private enterprises to establish track records and for private bankers to gain experience.
  • The legal system must adapt to a market economy after decades of communist rule.

docs.title: Key Takeaway
docs.text: • Understanding economic functions can be achieved by observing the consequences of their absence or dysfunction.

docs.title: Banking Systems in Former Communist Bloc Nations and Developing Countries
Foreign Ownership in Banking Assets
docs.text:
• In several former communist bloc nations, foreigners own a significant portion of banking assets:
    • Czech Republic: over 50%
    • Slovakia: over 50%
    • Romania: over 50%
    • Estonia: nearly all
    • Lithuania: over 50%
    • Hungary: over 50%
    • Bulgaria: over 50%
    • Poland: over 50%
    • Latvia: 60%

docs.title: Banking Challenges in India
docs.text:
• High rate of savings, but:
    • Low trust in banks leads to highest individual holdings of gold in the world
    • Only a small portion of savings is used for investment and output creation
    • 70% of savings in state-dominated banking system are lent to government or government-owned enterprises

docs.title: Banking Challenges in China
docs.text:
• High rate of savings, but:
    • 90% of savings go into government-owned banks with low interest rates
    • Subsidies government-owned enterprises with low returns on investment or operating losses
    • Most savings not allocated to efficient and prosperous private sector enterprises

docs.title: Government Ownership of Banks
docs.text:
• In countries like India and China, banks are owned by the government.
  • Government officials who run these banks often direct funds to state-owned enterprises.

docs.title: Inefficient Allocation of Resources
docs.text:
• This system leads to inefficient allocation of resources, as funds are not directed to the most profitable ventures.
  • Private banks, if allowed to operate freely, would lend to firms and industries that offer the highest rate of return.

docs.title: Consequences of Allowing Private Banks
docs.text:
• Higher interest rates for depositors, attracting savings away from state-run banks.
  • More efficient allocation of savings to successful businesses.
  • Higher rates of economic growth for the economy as a whole.

docs.title: Challenges for Government Officials
docs.text:
• Allowing private banks to operate freely would create challenges for government officials trying to sustain inefficient enterprises.
  • Economists may argue that these enterprises should go out of business, but government officials may be reluctant to see this happen due to personal career interests.

docs.title: The Problem with Meeting Unmet Needs
docs.text:
• Politicians often focus on meeting a specific unmet need, but this can lead to unintended consequences.
  • When another politician tries to address the negative consequences of the previous solution, resources are shifted in another direction, creating a cycle of inefficiency.

docs.title: The Limitations of Trade-Offs
docs.text:
• Trade-offs should be viewed as temporary solutions that may not fully meet unmet needs.
  • The concept of needs can be arbitrary and prioritize certain desires over others.

docs.title: The Importance of Balance
docs.text:
• Even essential resources like food, water, and oxygen are only necessary within a specific range.
  • Exceeding this range can lead to negative consequences, such as obesity, flooding damage, or even cancer growth.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
• Solutions should be approached with caution and consideration for the potential long-term effects.
  • A balanced approach is necessary to avoid creating new problems while trying to solve existing ones.

docs.title: Banking Risks
docs.text: Banks must manage not only money but also risk, including runs on banks and loan defaults. These risks can lead to financial losses and even destroy the institution.

docs.title: Government Impact on Banking Risks
docs.text:
Governments can influence banking risks through:

  • Property rights: Insecure property rights increase banking risks.
  • Regulation: Government regulation of banks can either increase or decrease riskiness.
    • Examples:
      • Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) in the United States
      • State deposit insurance laws

docs.title: Historical Context
docs.text:
• State deposit insurance laws: Preceded federal deposit insurance and were introduced to address increased risks created by states forbidding banks from having branch offices.
  • Outlawing branch banking: Initially intended to protect local banks from competition, but ultimately made banks more risky due to concentrated deposits and borrowers.

docs.title: Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Banking risks are significant and can be influenced by government actions.
  • Regulation can either increase or decrease riskiness in the banking sector.

docs.title: State Deposit Insurance
docs.text:
• Introduced to mitigate risks created by state banking regulation
  • Proved inadequate during the 1920s and Great Depression (1930s)
  • Thousands of American banks failed, mostly in small communities with laws against branch banking

docs.title: Federal Deposit Insurance
docs.text:
• Created in 1935 to end bank runs
  • Solved a problem largely created by other government interventions
  • However, deposit insurance can create new risks:
    • Encourages riskier behavior among insured individuals and institutions

docs.title: Canadian Banking System
docs.text:
• No banks failed during the same period when thousands of American banks were failing (1920s-1930s)
  • Despite lack of deposit insurance, Canada's banking system was more stable due to:
    • Fewer but larger banks with 3,000 branches across the country
    • Diversified risks among many locations with different economic conditions

docs.title: Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Deposit insurance is not a foolproof solution for mitigating banking risks
  • Regulation and government interventions can create new risks and unintended consequences
  • A more diversified and robust banking system, like Canada's, may be more effective in managing risk.

docs.title: Insurance and Risky Behavior
docs.text:
• Insurance can lead to riskier behavior as individuals or institutions may take on more risk than they would without insurance.
  • This is because insurance provides financial protection against losses, reducing the incentive to avoid risks.

docs.title: Example: Homeowners and Natural Disasters
docs.text:
• Without insurance, homeowners might choose to live in areas with lower risk of natural disasters like hurricanes or wildfires.
  • With insurance, they may be more willing to take on that risk and live in a more vulnerable area.

docs.title: Financial Institutions and Risky Investments
docs.text:
• Insured financial institutions, such as banks, may engage in riskier investments than they would without insurance.
  • Government restrictions can help minimize these risks, but the incentives for taking on risk remain.

docs.title: Government Intervention and Misjudging Risks
docs.text:
• Governments may misjudge some risks, leaving taxpayers liable for losses that exceed premium collections.
  • Examples of government intervention include the Community Reinvestment Act in the US, which aimed to direct investment into low-income communities.

docs.title: Community Reinvestment Act
docs.text:
• The act sought to make home-buying affordable to people with low incomes, substandard credit history, or lack of down payment.
  • It was re-invigorated during the 1990s and led to increased mortgage lending in low-income areas.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Governments pressured banks to lower mortgage approval standards to meet goals or quotas.
  • This led to riskier lending and higher rates of default in the early 21st century.
  • The collapse of banks, lending institutions, and Wall Street firms resulted from the decline in value of mortgage-based assets.

docs.title: Causes and Effects
docs.text: Cause Effect Government pressures on banks Riskier lending and higher default rates Lowered mortgage approval standards Collapse of banks and lending institutions Decline in monthly mortgage payments Decrease in value of mortgage-based assets

docs.title: Impact
docs.text:
• The collapse of financial institutions had far-reaching consequences for the economy.
  • The government's interference in banking practices contributed to the crisis.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• The study of human institutions involves finding the most tolerable imperfections.
  • A modern market economy cannot exist without a framework of rules and an authority to enforce them.

docs.title: Roles of Government
docs.text:
• Enforces its own rules
  • Enforces contracts and agreements among parties in the economy
  • Sets standards for measurement (e.g. pound, mile, bushel)
  • Supports itself through various means

docs.title: Importance of Government in a Market Economy
docs.text:
• Provides a necessary framework for market transactions to take place
  • Ensures that rules are enforced, providing stability and security for economic activity

docs.title: Role of Government in the Economy
Basic Functions of Government
docs.text:
• Collect taxes
  • Influence economic decision-making through taxation

docs.title: Expansive Roles of Government
docs.text:
• Direct ownership and operation of farms and industries
  • Controversies have raged globally for over a century on the role of government in the economy

docs.title: Historical Trends
docs.text:
• Early 20th century: Larger role for government in democratic and undemocratic countries (e.g., Soviet Union, China)
  • Late 20th century: Tide turned towards reducing government's role, starting in Britain and the United States
  • 1980s-1990s: Trend spread to other democratic countries and even Communist China

docs.title: Market Economies
docs.text:
• Emerged in Eastern Europe after collapse of Communism
  • Global shift towards market economies, with socialists embracing capitalism

docs.title: Notes on the Role of Government
Changes in Economic Systems
docs.text:
• Many countries are shifting from socialist to capitalist economies
  • Governments are selling off nationalized companies and seeking to attract back multinational corporations that were previously expelled

docs.title: The Importance of Experience
docs.text: • Bitter experiences have driven changes in economic systems more than new theories or analyses

docs.title: Providing a Framework of Law and Order
docs.text:
• Governments provide a framework within which people can engage in economic and other activities
  • This allows for mutual accommodations and agreements among individuals

docs.title: Accounting for External Costs and Benefits
docs.text:
• Certain activities generate significant costs or benefits that extend beyond the individuals involved
  • Governments can take account of these externalities when the marketplace does not

docs.title: Understanding Government Behavior
docs.text:
• Government is not a monolith nor simply the public interest personified
  • To understand government behavior, its incentives and constraints must be taken into account
  • Individuals working for government respond to incentives just like people in other human institutions

docs.title: The Importance of Law and Order in Economic Development
docs.text:
• A reliable framework of laws is essential for economic activity to flourish.
  • Such a framework may take centuries to achieve, but it is crucial for development.

docs.title: Corruption and Economic Underdevelopment
docs.text:
• Countries with ineffectual, arbitrary, or corrupt governments can remain poor despite abundant natural resources.
  • Lack of trust in the government discourages foreign and domestic investment.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• A reliable framework of laws is necessary for economic growth and prosperity.
  • Corruption and lack of effective governance can hinder economic development.
  • Prices and laws play crucial roles in facilitating market transactions and economic activity.

docs.title: Corruption and Inequality in Developing Countries
Congo
docs.text:
• Kinshasa, the capital city, is one of the world's poorest cities
  • Unsafe for arriving crews, who are shuttled elsewhere for overnight stays
  • Airport conditions are poor, with taxiing feeling like driving over railroad ties
  • Managers charge extra to turn on runway lights at night
  • Departing passengers face multiple layers of bribes before boarding

docs.title: Bolivia
docs.text:
• Law and order have broken down in the country
  • Police links to drug trafficking and stolen vehicles have been exposed
  • Nepotism and corruption within the police force are rampant
  • Officers on low salaries have been found living in mansions

docs.title: Egypt
docs.text:
• A high-profile businessman was sentenced to death for hiring a hitman to kill his former lover
