• Being able to buy goods at the lowest price available can be beneficial.
  • However, slippery words can make bad news look like good news and vice versa.

docs.title: Misleading Headlines
docs.text:
• Example: A Shrinking Trade Gap Looks Good Stateside (BusinessWeek magazine)
    • This headline was misleading as it occurred during a time of economic downturn:
      • Stock market falling
      • Unemployment rising
      • Corporate profits down
      • Total output of the American economy declined

docs.title: The Importance of Context
docs.text:
• Reduced imports can lead to a favorable balance of trade, but this does not necessarily indicate good economic health.
  • Example: The United States had a favorable balance of trade during the Great Depression of the 1930s.
  • In contrast, the country became a record-breaking debtor nation during the booming prosperity of the 1990s.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
• International trade words cannot be taken at face value as indicators of economic well-being.
  • It is necessary to examine more closely what such words mean in context.

docs.title: Why Countries Engage in International Trade
docs.text:
• Both sides gain from international trade
  • Economists group reasons for international trade into three categories: absolute advantage, comparative advantage, and economies of scale

docs.title: Absolute Advantage
docs.text:
• A country can produce a good at a lower cost than another country due to natural advantages (e.g., climate, soil)
  • Example: Bananas are grown more cheaply in tropical countries than in the United States
  • It is beneficial for Americans to buy bananas from tropical countries rather than growing them domestically at a higher cost

docs.title: Comparative Advantage and Economies of Scale
docs.text: • Not explicitly defined in this text snippet, but mentioned as two additional categories of reasons for international trade

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• International trade occurs because both sides gain
  • Natural advantages can lead to absolute advantage in producing certain goods
  • Countries should focus on producing goods in which they have a comparative advantage or economies of scale.

docs.title: Absolute Advantage in Production
docs.text:
• Certain countries have an absolute advantage in producing specific goods or services due to various factors such as:
    • Climate and geography (e.g., coffee production in Brazil, Vietnam, and Colombia)
    • Time zone differences (e.g., India's computer services for US companies)
    • Language skills (e.g., English-speaking Indian technicians)
    • Availability of skilled workers (e.g., India's large pool of software engineers)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
• Coffee Production: More than half the world's coffee is grown in Brazil, Vietnam, and Colombia due to their suitable climate and geography.
  • Computer Services: India's time zone difference and English-speaking technicians give it an advantage in providing round-the-clock computer services to US companies.
  • Fruit and Vegetable Supply: South American countries supply fruits and vegetables to North America during the winter months in the northern hemisphere.

docs.title: Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Absolute advantage refers to a country's ability to produce specific goods or services more cheaply or efficiently than other countries.
  • This advantage can arise from various factors, including climate, geography, time zone differences, language skills, and availability of skilled workers.

docs.title: Benefits of International Trade
docs.text:
• Foreigners benefit from lower costs while buying products from another country
  • The country itself benefits from a larger market for its products or services
  • Sometimes, inputs needed to create a product are free (e.g., warmth in the tropics or rich nutrients in the soil)

docs.title: Comparative Advantage
docs.text:
• A concept in economics that explains why countries trade with each other even if one country is more efficient than another
  • Definition: The ability of a country to produce a particular good or service at a lower opportunity cost than another country

docs.title: Illustration of Comparative Advantage
docs.text:
• Suppose Country A can produce anything more cheaply than Country B
  • However, producing more of one product means producing less of another product due to scarce resources with alternative uses
  • The question is not just about the cost of producing a product in each country, but also about the opportunity cost of producing one product instead of another

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Comparative advantage explains why countries trade with each other even if one country is more efficient than another
  • Opportunity costs play a crucial role in determining comparative advantage
  • Countries should specialize in producing goods and services for which they have a lower opportunity cost.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Countries can benefit from trading with each other if they have different trade-offs between producing two products.
  • A country can gain by specializing in the production of one good and importing the other.

docs.title: Production Possibilities
docs.text: Country Product Workers Output US Chairs 200 100,000 US TV Sets 300 60,000 Canada Chairs 200 90,000 Canada TV Sets 300 30,000

docs.title: Insights
docs.text:
• The US can produce more chairs and TV sets than Canada.
  • Canada has a comparative advantage in producing chairs, while the US has a comparative advantage in producing TV sets.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: Countries can benefit from international trade by specializing in the production of goods in which they have a comparative advantage. This leads to increased efficiency and productivity, allowing countries to produce more with their resources.

docs.title: Comparative Advantage and International Trade
docs.text:
Key Points

  • Specialization increases productivity: When countries specialize in producing goods where they have a comparative advantage, total output increases.
  • Comparative advantage vs. Absolute advantage: A country may not have an absolute advantage in producing a good, but still have a comparative advantage if it sacrifices fewer resources to produce that good.

Example: USA and Canada

Country Product Workers Output USA Chairs 500 225,000 USA TV Sets 500 100,000 Canada Chairs 500 190,000 Canada TV Sets 500 90,000

Without Specialization

  • Total output: 315,000 chairs and 190,000 TV sets

With Specialization

  • USA produces only TV Sets
  • Canada produces only Chairs
  • Total output: 225,000 chairs and 100,000 TV sets (USA) + 190,000 chairs (Canada) = 415,000 chairs and 100,000 TV sets

Conclusion

Specializing in producing goods where a country has a comparative advantage leads to increased productivity and total output. This is true even if a country does not have an absolute advantage in producing that good.

docs.title: The Reality of Homelessness
docs.text:
• As of 2013, over 47,000 people were homeless in New York, with 20,000 being children.
  • Despite available housing resources, people are forced to sleep outdoors due to inefficient allocation of resources.

docs.title: The Consequences of Inefficient Allocation
docs.text:
• The misallocation of resources can have severe consequences, including death from exposure on cold winter nights.
  • This highlights the real-world impact of economic concepts, such as efficient allocation of scarce resources.

docs.title: The Politics of Rent Control
docs.text:
• Rent control laws are often popular with politicians due to their potential to increase votes.
  • However, these laws can create serious economic and social problems, despite being politically effective.

docs.title: The Reality of Rent Control Laws
docs.text:
• The term affordable housing is misleading, as it does not necessarily reflect the actual consequences of rent control laws.
  • In reality, rates of return on investments in housing are often comparable to alternative investments, contradicting the narrative of greedy rich landlords.

docs.title: Definition
docs.text: Comparative advantage refers to the ability of an individual or country to produce a good or service at a lower opportunity cost than others.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Gains from Trade: Countries can benefit from trade by specializing in producing goods and services in which they have a comparative advantage.
  • Example: US and Canada: The US can get more chairs by trading TV sets with Canada, while Canada can get more TV sets by trading chairs with the US.
  • No Gain from Trade: If one country produces everything more efficiently than another by the same percentage for each product, there would be no gain from trade.

docs.title: Personal Level
docs.text:
• Example: Eye Surgeon: An eye surgeon should hire someone to wash their car instead of doing it themselves, even if they have experience and can do it faster.
  • Comparative Advantage: The surgeon has a comparative advantage in treating eye diseases over washing cars.

docs.title: Economic Reality
docs.text: • Scarcity: Individuals and countries face scarcity, with limited resources (e.g., time) to allocate between different activities.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Economic costs refer to the foregone alternatives or trade-offs made when choosing one option over another.
  • Countries have limited resources, including labor, time, and other factors of production, which means they must make choices about how to allocate these resources.
  • Comparative advantage is a concept that explains how countries can benefit from trade by specializing in producing goods and services for which they have a relative advantage.

docs.title: Benefits of Comparative Advantage
docs.text:
• Poorer countries can benefit from comparative advantage, as it allows them to produce goods and services that they can trade with other countries.
  • This leads to increased efficiency and productivity, as well as improved living standards.

docs.title: Real-World Example: Great Britain
docs.text:
• Great Britain has not produced enough food to feed its population for over a century.
  • However, by concentrating on producing goods and services in which it has a comparative advantage (such as manufacturing, shipping, and financial services), the country has been able to import food from other countries.
  • This has led to British consumers being better fed and having access to more manufactured goods than if the country had tried to produce everything domestically.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
• Comparative advantage is not just a theory, but an important fact in the history of many nations.
  • It highlights the importance of trade and specialization in achieving economic efficiency and improving living standards.

docs.title: Comparative Advantage
docs.text:
• A country should focus on producing goods for which it has a comparative advantage, rather than trying to produce everything domestically.
  • Even if a country's farmers are not as efficient as others, it may still be better off importing food from another country with a comparative advantage in agriculture.

Example: British Industry and Commerce

  • Transferring resources into agriculture to become self-sufficient in food would cost the British too much industry and commerce.
  • It is more beneficial for Britain to import food from other countries with a comparative advantage in agriculture.

Example: West African Cocoa Farmers

  • African farmers reduced their food production to plant cocoa trees, which earned them more money.
  • They were able to live off food produced elsewhere, including imported luxuries like canned fish and fruit.

docs.title: Economies of Scale
docs.text:
• Some products require huge investments in machinery, engineering, and specialized labor forces.
  • To be competitive, these products must be produced on a large scale, taking advantage of economies of scale.

docs.title: Economies of Scale in Automobile Production
Summary Notes
docs.text:
• The minimum output required to achieve efficient cost per car is between 200,000 to 400,000 automobiles per year.
  • Producing at this scale is feasible in large countries like the United States, where major automakers have achieved high sales volumes.
  • However, smaller countries like Australia face challenges in achieving economies of scale due to limited domestic demand.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• The Ford F-Series pickup truck has had annual sales of over 800,000 units.
  • In contrast, the largest number of cars sold in Australia is only about half the quantity needed to reap all cost benefits of economies of scale.
  • Australian car manufacturers rely on foreign-designed models from countries like Japan and the United States.

docs.title: Implications
docs.text:
• Smaller countries may struggle to establish a domestic automobile industry due to limitations in achieving economies of scale.
  • This can lead to reliance on foreign imports or partnerships with international companies.

docs.title: Summary Notes
docs.text:
Economies of Scale and International Trade

  • The Australian market is too small to support the production of original automobiles from scratch, making it difficult to compete with imported cars.
  • Australia's small population limits its total purchasing power, making it challenging for domestic businesses to achieve economies of scale.

Examples of Businesses that Thrive through Exports

  • Heineken sells beer in 170 countries, relying less on the small Holland market.
  • Nokia sells phones globally, not just in Finland.
  • The Economist magazine sells three times as many copies in the United States as in Britain.

Impact of International Trade on Businesses and Countries

  • Toyota, Honda, and Nissan earn most of their profits in North America.
  • Japanese automakers manufacture more cars outside of Japan than in Japan itself.
  • Small countries like South Korea and Taiwan rely heavily on international trade to produce products on a large scale.

Key Takeaway

International trade is necessary for many countries and businesses to achieve economies of scale, increase profitability, and expand their global presence.

docs.title: Economies of Scale and International Trade
Key Points
docs.text:
• Economies of scale allow countries to sell products at competitive prices in the world market.
  • Large investments in machinery and research require huge outputs to repay costs, which may not be possible through domestic sales alone.
  • International trade enables more economies of scale around the world, even in countries with small domestic markets.

docs.title: Benefits of International Trade
docs.text:
• Creates greater efficiency by allowing countries to take advantage of their absolute or comparative advantages.
  • Enables mass production industries to operate efficiently, even if domestic markets are not large enough to absorb all output.

docs.title: Case Study: India's Import Restrictions
docs.text:
• For many years, India encouraged small businesses and maintained barriers to imports that could compete with them.
  • The lifting of import restrictions at the end of the 20th century led to a flood of cheap imports from countries like China.
  • Example: A Chinese-made plastic doll that sings popular Hindi film songs and costs only 100 rupees (S2) became a huge hit in Indian markets, leaving local toy companies struggling to compete.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: International trade enables economies of scale and creates greater efficiency by allowing countries to take advantage of their strengths. It also exposes domestic industries to competition from cheaper imports, which can be beneficial for consumers but challenging for local businesses.

docs.title: India's Economic Challenges
docs.text:
• India's toy manufacturers face economic problems due to free trade, but these issues are overshadowed by the consequences of previous import restrictions.
  • These restrictions forced millions of people in India to pay inflated prices for products, protecting small-scale producers from competition.

docs.title: Impact of Import Restrictions
docs.text:
• Decades of protectionist policies ended in India in the late 20th century.
  • Such policies artificially kept Indian producers small, making it difficult for them to compete with larger producers abroad.

docs.title: International Trade and Efficiency
docs.text:
• International trade brings advantages to the world and individual countries by increasing economic efficiency.
  • However, this increased efficiency can displace less efficient industries and businesses.

docs.title: Examples of Displacement
docs.text:
• The rise of automobiles led to severe losses for horse-and-buggy manufacturers.
  • The spread of giant supermarket chains drove many small neighborhood grocery stores out of business.

docs.title: Summary Notes
docs.text:
• Comparative Advantage: Imports can lead to losses in revenue and jobs in domestic industries where other countries have a comparative advantage.
  • Economic Gains vs. Losses: While imports create economic gains, these are often outweighed by political pressure for protectionism.

docs.title: Common Fallacies
docs.text:
• Wealthy Countries Can't Compete with Low-Wage Countries: This argument is often used to justify trade restrictions.
  • Poorer Countries Need Protection for Infant Industries: Some argue that developing countries need protection from more developed nations until they acquire the necessary experience and know-how.

docs.title: Complaints of Unfairness
docs.text:
• Dumping: Some countries are accused of selling goods at artificially low prices to gain a larger market share, which can lead to monopolistic practices.
  • Lack of Fairness in Import/Export Laws: Countries often complain that others have unfair laws and regulations regarding international trade.

docs.title: The Complexity of Real-Life Trade
docs.text: • No Argument is 100% Right or Wrong: In reality, arguments for and against free trade are nuanced and context-dependent.

docs.title: The High-Wage Fallacy
docs.text:
• Argument: American workers cannot compete with low-wage workers in poorer countries.
  • Counterargument:
    • Historical evidence shows high-wage countries have been exporting to low-wage countries for centuries (e.g., Dutch Republic, Britain).
    • Examples of high-wage countries successfully competing with low-wage countries (e.g., Japan, US vs. India).

Key Points

  • High-wage countries can compete with low-wage countries through international trade.
  • Historical evidence supports this claim.
  • Restricting imports can harm domestic producers in the long run.

Examples

  • Dutch Republic: A leader in international trade from 1590s to 1740s, despite having some of the highest-paid workers in the world.
  • Britain: The world's greatest exporter in the 19th century, with higher wage rates than many countries it sold to.
  • India: Restricted imports of automobiles and other products made in Japan and the US, but eased restrictions later on.

docs.title: Notes on International Trade and Labor Costs
Key Points
docs.text:
• The Tata group in India has set up an office to educate its employees on the potential impact of removing import restrictions, despite China having higher wages.
  • A silk tie bought in China costs 85 rupees, while a similar tie made in India would cost 400 rupees.

docs.title: Flaws in the High-Wage Argument
docs.text:
• Confuses wage rates with labor costs and labor costs with total costs.
  • Wage rates are measured per hour of work, while labor costs are measured per unit of output.
  • Total costs include not only labor but also capital, raw materials, transportation, and other expenses.

docs.title: Labor Costs and Productivity
docs.text:
• When workers in a prosperous country produce three times the output per hour as those in a poorer country, despite receiving twice the wages, the high-wage country has lower labor costs per unit of output.
  • It is cheaper to get work done in the more prosperous country due to increased productivity.

docs.title: Implications
docs.text:
• Higher wages do not necessarily mean higher labor costs or total costs.
  • Increased productivity can lead to lower labor costs and a competitive advantage.

docs.title: Page 74
docs.text: Summary Notes

docs.title: Rent Control and Landlord Economics
docs.text:
• Many landlords are people of modest means, especially those owning small, low-end apartment buildings.
  • These landlords often use their own skills and labor to maintain the premises while trying to pay off the mortgage with rent collections.

docs.title: Effects of Blanket Rent Control Laws
docs.text:
• Applying rent control laws to all existing housing can lead to luxurious housing becoming low-rent housing.
  • Over time, it becomes clear that no new housing will be built unless exempted from rent control, leading to exemptions or relaxations for new housing.

docs.title: Consequences of Non-Comparability of Rents
docs.text:
• New apartments, even if modest in size and quality, may rent for more than older, more spacious, and luxurious apartments under rent control.
  • This non-comparability of rents is common in European cities and American cities with rent control laws, such as New York City.

docs.title: Real-World Example
docs.text: • A news story in the Wall Street Journal highlighted this issue in New York City's rent control laws.

docs.title: Notes on International Labor Productivity and Wage Rates
Key Points
docs.text:
• Higher-paid workers are not necessarily more expensive to hire
  • Productivity, organization, management, machinery, and economies of scale can affect labor costs per unit of output
  • Transportation costs and other factors can influence total costs of delivering a product to market

docs.title: Labor Productivity Comparison: India vs. United States
docs.text:
• Average labor productivity in modern sectors in India is 15% of that in the United States
  • Hiring an Indian worker at 20% of an American worker's wage would still increase labor costs due to lower productivity

docs.title: Implications for Low-Wage Countries
docs.text: • Low-wage countries can only gain jobs at the expense of high-wage countries if the difference in productivity is less than the difference in wages paid.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: Higher wage rates per unit of time do not necessarily mean higher labor costs per unit of output. Labor productivity, among other factors, plays a crucial role in determining the true cost of hiring workers.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Comparative Advantage: Jobs will shift to countries with specific advantages in certain areas, such as India's skilled computer programmers.
  • No Net Loss of Jobs: While some jobs may be lost due to international competition, restrictions on trade usually result in a net loss of jobs and reduced economic prosperity.
  • Labor Costs vs. Capital Costs: Labor costs are only part of the story; capital costs can exceed labor costs, especially in industries with high fixed costs (e.g., electric utilities and railroads).
  • Capital Abundance and Cost: A prosperous country tends to have a greater abundance of capital, making it cheaper than in poorer countries where capital is scarcer.

docs.title: Implications
docs.text:
• Globalization leads to job shifts based on comparative advantage.
  • Restricting trade can harm economic prosperity and result in net job losses.
  • Capital costs play a significant role in industry competitiveness.
  • Economic prosperity affects the availability and cost of capital.

docs.title: Investment and Capital Costs
docs.text:
• Wealthy countries can earn higher returns on investments due to lower capital costs.
  • As more investors enter a market, the rate of return declines (e.g., Russia's rate of return fell below 5% by 1900).
  • Poorer countries face difficulties competing with richer countries due to high capital costs.

docs.title: Trade and Competition
docs.text:
• Some industries may be adversely affected by imported products, but this is also true for domestic competition.
  • Foreign competition can lead to modernization, downsizing, or businesses going out of business.

docs.title: Politics and Protectionism
docs.text:
• Politicians often face pressure to restrict imports during periods of high unemployment.
  • Restricting imports can be depicted as a case of our country versus theirs, but it's actually about domestic interests versus consumers.

docs.title: Historical Example: The 1930s Depression
docs.text:
• Tariff barriers and restrictions rose globally, resulting in world exports being only one-third of their former level by 1933.
  • This protectionism had tragic consequences during the Great Depression.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The passage discusses how trade restrictions, such as tariffs, can have negative consequences on a country's economy. It specifically mentions the Smoot-Hawley tariffs passed in the United States in 1930, which led to retaliatory measures from other countries.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Trade restrictions reduce economic efficiency: Trade restrictions, like tariffs, lower standards of living and do not produce increased employment.
  • Smoot-Hawley tariffs sparked global trade restrictions: The passage of the Smoot-Hawley tariffs in 1930 led to severe international trade restrictions by many countries.
  • Retaliation from other countries: Other countries retaliated with their own trade restrictions on American products.
  • Economic consequences were unexpected but predicted: Over a thousand economists had predicted that the tariff increases would not lead to increased employment, and instead would have negative economic consequences.

docs.title: Quotes
docs.text:
• We cannot increase employment by restricting trade.
  • America is now suffering from the problem of unemployment: The proponents of higher tariffs claim that an increase in rates will give work to the idle. This is not true.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: Trade restrictions, such as tariffs, can have far-reaching and negative consequences on a country's economy. It is essential to consider the potential outcomes of such measures before implementing them.

docs.title: Summary Notes
docs.text:
The Smoot-Hawley Tariffs: A Recipe for Disaster

  • Predictions Fulfilled: Economists predicted retaliatory tariffs against the US by other countries, losses for American farmers, and increased unemployment. All these predictions came true.
  • Unemployment Soared: The unemployment rate in the US rose from 6% in June 1930 to 15% a year later and eventually reached 26%.
  • Trade Declined: US farm exports plummeted, and international trade declined.

The Dark Side of Protectionism

  • Short-term Gains, Long-term Pains: Protective tariffs may provide temporary relief to specific industries, but they come at the expense of others.
  • Unintended Consequences: Tariffs can lead to devastating economic consequences, as seen in the US steel industry's decline.

Key Statistics

  • Unemployment rate in June 1930: 6%
  • Unemployment rate a year later: 15%
  • Unemployment rate eventually reached: 26%
  • Number of jobs in the American steel industry in the 1980s:
    • Started at: 340,000
    • Ended at: 125,000

docs.title: Protectionism: The Dark Side of Tariffs
Summary
docs.text: The text discusses the negative consequences of protectionist policies, specifically tariffs on steel and sugar imports in the United States. While these measures may have benefited specific industries, they ultimately harmed American workers and industries as a whole.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Steel Tariffs: Led to higher steel costs for American industries, making them less competitive globally.
    • Estimated benefits: $240 million in profits for steel companies, 5,000 jobs saved.
    • Estimated losses: $600 million in profits lost by other industries, 26,000 jobs lost.
  • Sugar Import Restrictions: Saved jobs in the sugar industry but cost three times as many jobs in the confection industry due to high sugar costs.
    • Some American firms relocated to Canada and Mexico for lower sugar costs.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: Protectionist policies may provide short-term benefits to specific industries, but they ultimately lead to negative consequences for the broader economy and workforce.

docs.title: Fallacy of Composition
docs.text:
• The belief that what is true for a part is true for the whole
  • International trade restrictions can benefit specific industries, but not necessarily the economy as a whole

docs.title: Infant Industries Argument
docs.text:
• Protecting new industries temporarily until they can compete with established foreign competitors
  • In theory, protection should be removed once the industry is developed
  • In practice:
    • New industries often lack political influence to gain protection
    • Old, inefficient industries may retain enough influence to obtain protection

docs.title: Example: US Sugar Industry
docs.text:
• 2000-2012: Average price of sugar in the US was more than double the world market price (Wall Street Journal)
  • Production shifted from Hawaii and Louisiana to a factory in Guatemala that opened in 2010

docs.title: Protectionist Legislation and Subsidies
docs.text:
• Governments may implement protectionist policies or provide subsidies to preserve domestic industries at the expense of consumers and taxpayers.
  • This is often justified as essential for national defense.

docs.title: National Defense and Domestic Supplies
docs.text:
• Most advocates of trade agree that depending on imports from potential enemy nations for military equipment and supplies is undesirable.
  • Therefore, governments support domestic suppliers of munitions and weapons of war to ensure availability in times of need.

docs.title: Historical Example: Colonial America
docs.text: • In colonial America, American Indians relied on European settlers for guns and ammunition, which ultimately led to their defeat when they ran out of bullets during warfare.

docs.title: Preference for Domestic Suppliers
docs.text:
• Countries generally prefer having domestic suppliers for products essential to national survival.
  • The term essential to national defense can be stretched to include products only remotely related to national security.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The argument for international trade restrictions for national defense purposes can be valid, but its validity depends on specific circumstances. The probability of a foreign country becoming an enemy varies, affecting the dangers of relying on them for military equipment.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• National defense labels can be used to protect products from international competition for self-serving reasons.
  • Different countries pose different probabilities of becoming future enemies, affecting the risks of relying on their suppliers.
  • The export of technology, not just physical goods, can represent a military threat.
  • Politicians, not economists, often favor lifting international trade restrictions, even if it compromises national defense.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
• In 2004, Canada was the largest foreign recipient of Pentagon contracts ($601 million), followed by Britain and Israel.
  • The US lifted bans on selling advanced computer technology to China in the 1990s, despite objections from US military authorities.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
• Argument for government protection against foreign competitors: dumping products at prices below production costs to drive domestic producers out of business.
  • Governments have passed anti-dumping laws to ban, restrict, or heavily tax imports from companies deemed guilty of dumping.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Determining production costs is difficult, especially when investigating companies in other countries.
  • Domestic producers can easily bring dumping charges against foreign competitors when they lose customers to imports.
  • Anti-dumping laws rely on accurate determination of production costs, which is often challenging.

docs.title: Implications
docs.text:
• Anti-dumping laws may be used as a protectionist measure rather than a legitimate response to unfair trade practices.
  • The complexity of determining production costs can lead to arbitrary or biased decisions.
  • Domestic producers may use anti-dumping laws to restrict competition and maintain market share.

docs.title: Rent Control in New York City
docs.text:
• Two contrasting examples of rent-controlled apartments in Manhattan:
    • A small studio apartment on the Upper West Side with 2 roommates, renting for $1,200/month.
    • A spacious 2-bedroom apartment on Park Avenue with solarium and two terraces, worth at least $5,000/month, but rented by a private investor and his wife for around $350/month.
  • Rent control laws in New York City benefit the affluent and wealthy more than the poor.

docs.title: Statistical Study Findings
docs.text:
• The biggest difference between prices under rent control law and free-market prices is in apartments.
  • The affluent and wealthy receive more economic benefits from rent control than the poor.

docs.title: Welfare Agencies and Rent Payments
docs.text:
• City welfare agencies pay much higher rents for poverty-stricken families housed in cramped and run-down hotels.
  • In 2013, the city's Department of Homeless Services spent over $3,000/month for each threadbare room without a bathroom or kitchen in a single room occupancy hotel.

docs.title: Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Rent control laws can have unintended consequences, benefiting the wealthy more than the poor.
  • Welfare agencies pay high rents for substandard housing, highlighting the need for reform.

docs.title: Anti-Dumping Laws and Uncertainties in Determining Cost
docs.text:
• Authorities often accept dumping charges due to uncertainties in determining cost.
  • The European Union has imposed anti-dumping laws on various products, including:
    • Mountain bikes from Thailand
    • Bed linen from Egypt
    • Antibiotics from India
    • Footwear from China
    • Microwave ovens from Malaysia
    • Monosodium glutamate from Brazil

docs.title: Case Study: Thai Mountain Bike Producer
docs.text:
• The EU declared that a Thai producer was exporting mountain bikes to Europe below their cost of production.
  • However, the producer's costs in selling large numbers of bikes in Europe were likely lower than those of other producers selling smaller numbers in Thailand.
  • Selling bikes in Europe for less than the price charged in Thailand did not necessarily mean selling below the cost of producing bikes for the European market.

docs.title: Similar Situations
docs.text:
• The United States has also applied anti-dumping laws to various products, including:
    • Steel from Japan
    • Aluminum from Russia
    • Golf carts from large countries

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
• US government agencies use best information available to determine production costs, often supplied by American businesses competing with foreign products.
  • Anti-dumping laws are part of protectionism, favoring domestic producers over consumers.

docs.title: Problems with Dumping Theory
docs.text:
• Similar to predatory pricing theory, which has problems discussed in Chapter 8.
  • Easy to charge, hard to prove or disprove, both domestically and internationally.
  • Political bias can lead to accepting charges without proof.

docs.title: Tariffs
docs.text:
• Taxes on imports that raise prices and enable domestic producers to charge more for competing products.
  • Example: $10 tariff on imported widgets allows domestic producers to charge $10 more than they could with cheaper foreign competition.

docs.title: Import Quotas
docs.text:
• Restrict foreign companies from competing fairly with domestic producers.
  • Effects may not be as obvious to the public as tariffs, but can have similar economic end results.

docs.title: Summary Notes
docs.text:
Trade Restrictions and Their Effects

  • Quota limitations on imported goods can drive up prices through supply and demand
  • These effects may be harder to quantify for the voting public, making it easier for elected officials to pass such restrictions
  • Countries often impose unfair restrictions on imports in response to internal interests
  • Responding with similar restrictions will only deprive both countries of more benefits from international trade

Disguises for Trade Restrictions

  • Health and safety rules applied to imports can be excessive and restrictive
  • Red tape requirements can add significant costs, especially for perishable imports
  • These measures are often used as disguises for trade restrictions and have similar effects to import quotas

Key Points

  • International trade restrictions can have far-reaching consequences
  • Countries should consider the long-term benefits of free trade rather than responding with restrictive measures
  • Transparency and quantification of effects can help voters make informed decisions about trade policies

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Comparative advantages can shift over time, leading to changes in international production centers.
  • The United States initially had a comparative advantage in computer development and production, but as technology improved, production shifted to poorer countries overseas.
  • Despite this, the US retained its comparative advantage in software design.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
• Computer manufacturing: Initially developed in the US, later shifted to Asia (e.g., Taiwan) for assembly.
  • Asian firms rely on US, Japanese, and European firms for new technology, while making thin margins due to licensing fees charged by global brand firms.

docs.title: Observations
docs.text:
• Comparative advantages can change rapidly with technological advancements.
  • International trade patterns can shift significantly as a result of these changes.

docs.title: Notes on International Trade and Job Creation
Comparative Advantage and Job Movement
docs.text:
• The US computer software industry expanded successfully because American engineers and technicians focused on high-comparative-advantage areas.
  • Labor cannot be in two places at once, so it moves to where its comparative advantage is greatest, even if this means losing jobs in areas with no comparative advantage.

docs.title: Prosperity and Job Growth through Free Trade
docs.text:
• The US experienced unprecedented prosperity and rapidly growing employment during times of significant layoffs in some industries.
  • International free trade created new, well-paying jobs across various companies and regions.

docs.title: Political Influence and Trade Restrictions
docs.text:
• Laws are often passed to restrict international trade, benefiting concentrated and vocal constituencies (e.g., labor unions and employer associations).
  • These restrictions may cause greater nationwide job losses but carry more political weight due to the concentration of economic interest and clout.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Comparative advantage drives job movement and creation.
  • Free trade can lead to prosperity and job growth, even in the face of layoffs in certain industries.
  • Political influence often favors concentrated interests over broader national benefits.

docs.title: Definition of Outsourcing
docs.text:
• The direct transfer of particular jobs to a foreign country.
  • Examples: American or British telephone-answering jobs transferred to India.

docs.title: Misconceptions about Outsourcing
docs.text:
• Critics often focus on the number of jobs lost, but not the number of jobs gained through outsourcing in the other direction.
  • Many countries outsource jobs to the United States, just as many U.S. companies outsource jobs abroad.

docs.title: Examples of Foreign Companies Creating Jobs in the US
docs.text:
• Siemens (Germany) employs tens of thousands of Americans in the United States.
  • Honda and Toyota (Japan) also employ large numbers of Americans in the United States.
  • As of 2006, 63% of Japanese brand automobiles sold in the United States were manufactured in the United States.

docs.title: Net Job Creation through Outsourcing
docs.text:
• Between 1977 and 2001, foreign-owned multinational companies created 4.7 million jobs in the United States.
  • The total number of Americans employed by foreign multinational companies runs into the millions.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
• Outsourcing is a two-way street, with both job losses and gains occurring simultaneously.
  • It's essential to consider the net impact of outsourcing on employment rather than just focusing on one side of the equation.

docs.title: Impact of Outsourcing on American Jobs
docs.text:
• Between 1977 and 1994, American-owned multinational companies created only 2.8 million new jobs in the US.
  • In contrast, more American jobs were sent abroad by these companies than were created in the US by foreign multinationals during the last decade of that period.

docs.title: Net Effect of Outsourcing on Jobs
docs.text:
• The net difference in numbers of jobs is small compared to the country's total employment.
  • Outsourcing can lead to increased efficiency and wealth creation, resulting in more jobs in the economy as a whole.

docs.title: Public Perception of Free Trade
docs.text:
• Despite widespread support among economists, free trade has limited public support.
  • An international survey by The Economist found that more people favored protectionism than free trade in several countries, including Britain, France, Italy, Australia, Russia, and the US.

docs.title: Costs and Benefits of Protectionism
docs.text:
• Protectionism saves relatively few jobs at a high cost: an estimated 200,000 jobs saved in European Union countries at a cost of $43 billion.
  • The public often has no idea how much protectionism costs and how little net benefit it produces.

docs.title: Page 757
docs.text: Notes on Protectionism and Free Trade

docs.title: The Cost of Job Protection
docs.text:
• Protecting jobs through tariffs costs $215,000 per year for each job saved
  • This amount is so high that even if workers who lost their jobs due to foreign competition were compensated with $100,000 per year, the EU would still come out ahead by allowing free international trade

docs.title: Inefficient Production and Resource Allocation
docs.text:
• The cost of keeping workers in unproductive jobs is not just their salaries, but also the larger costs of producing goods inefficiently
  • These inefficiencies waste scarce resources that could be used more productively elsewhere
  • As a result, the losses to consumers far outweigh the gains to workers, making society as a whole worse off

docs.title: Public Support for Protectionism and Economist's Role
docs.text:
• Many economists do not effectively counter protectionist arguments, despite them being refuted centuries ago
  • This has allowed articulate spokesmen for protectionism to have a free hand in promoting their views
  • Economists should do more to educate the public about the benefits of free trade and the costs of protectionism.

docs.title: Historical Perspective
docs.text: • As early as 1828, British economist Nassau W. Senior argued that high wages were a consequence of England's superior productivity, not a barrier to competition with foreign countries

docs.title: The Lack of Engagement from Economists on Free Trade
docs.text:
• Economists have generally reacted with contempt and indifference to protectionist arguments, refusing to engage in public debates.
  • This lack of engagement has allowed critics of free trade to monopolize public opinion.

docs.title: A Public Debate Experience
docs.text:
• Jagdish Bhagwati, a renowned economist, shared his experience of engaging in a public debate on free trade with Ralph Nader at Cornell University.
  • Despite giving a technical talk on free trade to graduate students earlier that day, none of them attended the debate, illustrating the typical reaction of why waste one's time?
  • The majority of the nearly thousand students who attended the debate were anti-free traders, rooting for Nader.

docs.title: Misconceptions about Globalization
docs.text:
• The term globalization has led many to believe that international trade and financial transactions are a new phenomenon.
  • This misconception allows special interests and ideologues to manipulate public opinion.

docs.title: Definition
docs.text:
• Globalization is more than just simple free trade among nations.
  • It includes institutional rules governing:
    • Reduction of trade barriers
    • Movements of money

docs.title: International Organizations Involved
docs.text:
• World Bank
  • International Monetary Fund (IMF)
  • World Trade Organization (WTO)

docs.title: Controversies
docs.text:
• Rules governing globalization are legitimate subjects of controversy.
  • Not all controversies are about free trade.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: Rent control laws are often perceived as protecting poor tenants from rich landlords. However, the reality is more complex.

docs.title: Reality of Rent Control
docs.text:
• Beneficiaries can be at any income level, not just low-income individuals.
  • Those who lose out can also be at any income level.
  • It depends on who is on the inside looking out and who is on the outside looking in when laws are passed.

docs.title: Case Study: San Francisco
docs.text:
• Rent control laws have been in place since 1979.
  • A 2001 study showed that over one-fourth of rent-controlled apartment occupants had household incomes above $100,000/year.
  • This was the first empirical study of rent control commissioned by the city.
  • Despite no serious attempt to measure consequences, these laws were enforced and extended for over two decades.

docs.title: Unintended Consequences
docs.text:
• Cities with strong rent control laws (e.g., New York, San Francisco) tend to have higher average rents than cities without rent control.
  • Builders are incentivized to build only luxurious apartments priced above the rent-control level, leading to:
    • Higher average rents in the city.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Rent control laws can benefit anyone, regardless of income level.
  • Strong rent control laws can lead to higher average rents.
  • Unintended consequences can occur when builders are incentivized to build only luxury apartments.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• The financial industry is highly globalized due to the portability and widespread use of its product, money.
  • International transfers of wealth occur in various forms.

docs.title: Forms of International Transfers of Wealth
docs.text:
• Direct Investment: Individuals and businesses invest directly in business enterprises of another country.
    • Example: Americans invested $329 billion in other countries, while foreigners invested $168 billion in the United States in 2012.

docs.title: Notable Facts
docs.text: • The United States is both a major source and recipient of foreign investment.

docs.title: Indirect Foreign Investment
docs.text:
• Citizens can invest money in another country's banks, which then lend to individuals and enterprises
  • Example: 46% of publicly held US government bonds are held by people in other countries

docs.title: Remittances
docs.text:
• People living in foreign countries send money back to family members in their home countries
  • Statistics:
    • In 2012, 250 million migrants sent remittances of $410 billion
    • In Mexico (2011): one-fifth of the population received money from family members in the US, totaling nearly $23 billion
    • Emigrants from India and China sent $64 billion and $62 billion back home, respectively

docs.title: Economic Impact of Remittances
docs.text:
• Significant economic impact on poor countries:
    • Accounts for about 60% of income for poorest households in Guatemala
    • Helped reduce poverty by 11 percentage points in Uganda and 6 percentage points in Bangladesh (World Bank studies)

docs.title: Importance of International Remittances
docs.text:
• Money sent back to Lebanon equals 22% of its GDP
  • Remittances to Moldova equal 23% of its GDP, and for Tajikistan, 35%
  • International remittances play a crucial role in supporting poor people in poor countries

docs.title: Historical Examples of Wealth Transfers
docs.text:
• Irish immigrants in America sent remittances back to their families in Ireland during the 1840s famine
  • Imperial powers looted wealth from conquered nations:
    • Alexander the Great took treasures from the Persians
    • Spain took gold and silver from indigenous peoples in the Western Hemisphere
    • Julius Caesar marched through Rome displaying riches and slaves from his victories

docs.title: Modern Forms of Wealth Transfers
docs.text: • Foreign aid: prosperous nations and international agencies transfer wealth to poorer countries

docs.title: Key Takeaway
docs.text: • When considering international trade and transfers of wealth, remember Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes' advice to think things instead of words

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Theoretically, investments should flow from capital-abundant countries to capital-scarce countries. However, this is not what usually happens in the real world.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• In 2012, only 12% of international bank loans ($2.5 trillion out of $21 trillion) went to poor countries.
  • Less than 7% of international investment securities ($400 billion out of $6 trillion) went to poor countries.
  • Rich countries tend to invest in other rich countries.

docs.title: Reasons for this trend
docs.text:
• Fear of unstable governments and policy changes that can affect investment conditions.
  • Risk of not getting money back due to drastic changes or outright expropriation.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: International investments do not always follow theoretical expectations, and there are valid reasons why rich countries tend to invest in other rich countries rather than poor ones.

docs.title: Deterrents to Investment
docs.text:
• Confiscation and Nationalization: Government seizure of assets can deter investment.
  • Corruption: Widespread corruption can discourage economic activity and investment. Countries with high levels of corruption (e.g., Nigeria, Russia) are less likely to attract international investments.

docs.title: Impact of Corruption on Prosperity
docs.text:
• Countries with low levels of corruption tend to be prosperous (e.g., European countries, Japan, Singapore).
  • Honesty has serious economic implications for a country's prosperity.

docs.title: Capital Movement and Investment
docs.text:
• Restrictions on Capital Flow: Poorer countries that restrict capital movement are less likely to attract investments.
  • Example: Hong Kong: Under British rule, Hong Kong developed into an industrial powerhouse due to its secure laws, low tax rates, and free flow of capital and trade.

docs.title: Economic Reforms and Investment
docs.text: • India's Loosening of Government Controls: Since relaxing government controls over the economy, India has seen significant investment inflows, particularly in regions like Bangalore with a concentrated supply of skilled workers.

docs.title: Key Principles
docs.text:
• International trade balances in gross terms
  • Wealth transfer occurs through imports and exports
  • Accounting conventions may differ from economic realities

docs.title: The Example of Japan-US Trade
docs.text:
• Japan has a net surplus in its trade with the US
  • Japanese automakers receive billions of dollars in American money
  • This money is invested back into the US economy, rather than being taken out of the country

docs.title: What Happens to the Money?
docs.text:
• Japanese companies invest in US assets, such as real estate (e.g. Rockefeller Center)
  • They also buy goods and services from other countries, including the US
  • The money remains within the US economy, rather than leaving the country

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
• International trade and wealth transfer are complex processes that involve both economic realities and accounting conventions.
  • Understanding these principles is essential for analyzing global economic trends and making informed decisions.

docs.title: Summary Notes
docs.text:
Honda and Toyota's US Factories

  • Employ thousands of American workers
  • Manufacture cars closer to customers to avoid shipping costs across the Pacific Ocean
  • Employees have high wages and have voted against joining labor unions in secret ballot elections
  • Example: 10 millionth Toyota built in the US on July 29, 2002

International Trade Balance

  • Consists only of physical goods that move between countries
  • Does not include services (e.g. houses, haircuts, surgery)
  • US economy produces more services than goods, leading to:
    • Importing more goods than exporting
    • Exporting more services than importing

Accounting Convention

  • International trade balance does not count foreign payments for American services (e.g. Microsoft operating systems)
  • This is an accounting convention, not a reflection of the actual economic activity

Key Takeaways

  • The US economy produces more services than goods
  • International trade balance is only one part of the economic picture
  • Accounting conventions can influence how economic data is reported in the media

docs.title: The Trade Deficit: A Misleading Indicator?
docs.text:
• The trade deficit is often misunderstood and misrepresented in the media.
  • The United States earns a substantial surplus from its services, such as royalty and license fees, which are omitted from the trade balance.

Key Statistics

  • In 2012, the US earned $124 billion from royalty and license fees alone.
  • The US supplied over $628 billion worth of services to other countries in 2012.
  • This amount is more than double the GDP of Egypt or Malaysia.

Perspective on Trade Deficits

  • The Wall Street Journal ranks trade deficits as a relatively minor economic concern (75th).
  • Politicians' reactions, such as imposing new trade barriers or devaluing currency, are a greater worry.
  • The size of the trade deficit relative to the economy's overall size is more important than its absolute value.

Comparing Trade Deficits

  • The US has the world's largest trade deficit, but also the world's largest economy.
  • In 2011, the American trade deficit was under 5% of GDP, less than half that of Turkey and less than one-fourth that of Macedonia.

Balance of Payments vs. Balance of Trade

  • When considering all money and resources moving in and out of a country, the term balance of payments is more accurate.
  • This includes payments for goods and services, providing a broader perspective on trade deficits.

docs.title: Balance of Trade: Not the Whole Story
docs.text:
• The balance of trade is not necessarily connected to a country's economic health.
  • A trade surplus does not guarantee prosperity, and a deficit does not guarantee poverty.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
• The US had a rare balance of payments surplus in the late 20th century, but it was followed by a recession in 1992.
  • Germany regularly runs export surpluses, but its economy has slower growth rates and higher unemployment rates than the US.
  • Nigeria often has international trade surpluses, but it is one of the poorest countries in the world.

docs.title: Foreign Investments: Misleading Data
docs.text:
• When foreigners invest in a country, it can make that country appear as a debtor due to accounting rules.
  • Foreigners invested $12 billion in American businesses in 1980, rising to over $200 billion annually by 1998.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
• Trade and investment data should be considered in context and not taken at face value.
  • These numbers do not necessarily indicate a country's economic prosperity or poverty.

docs.title: Foreign Investment in the United States
Key Points
docs.text:
• The US received over twice as much foreign investment as any other country in the world.
  • As of 2012, foreigners bought $400 billion more assets in the US than Americans acquired abroad.
  • Most foreign investment (60%) comes from Europe, with another 9% from Canada.

docs.title: Benefits of Foreign Investment
docs.text:
• Creates more wealth in the US
  • Generates jobs for American workers
  • Provides goods for American consumers
  • Offers income to foreign investors

docs.title: Concerns about Foreign Investment
docs.text:
• Growing debt to foreigners
  • Annual balance of payments deficits and accumulated international debt rise with a prosperous economy

docs.title: Impact on the US Economy
docs.text:
• Record levels of international deficits and debts accompanied the prosperity of the US economy in the 1990s.
  • The US was a prime destination for foreign investment, attracting many investors seeking to benefit from its economic growth.

docs.title: Rent Control and Homelessness
docs.text:
• Rent control laws can lead to increased homelessness, especially in cities like New York and San Francisco.
  • The political success of rent control laws is partly due to people's misconception that they actually control rents.

docs.title: Scarcity vs. Shortage
docs.text:
• Scarcity: a situation where fewer goods are available relative to the population.
  • Shortage: a price phenomenon, not necessarily related to scarcity.
  • Examples:
    • Housing shortage in the US during and after WWII, despite no change in housing-to-population ratio.
    • Destruction of over half of San Francisco's housing supply in 1906, without resulting in a shortage.

docs.title: Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Rent control laws can have unintended consequences, such as increased homelessness.
  • Understanding the distinction between scarcity and shortage is crucial for effective economic analysis.

docs.title: Notes on International Investments and Debts
Key Points
docs.text:
• A country's creditor or debtor status is not inherently good or bad, but depends on its specific circumstances, opportunities, and constraints.
  • Switzerland, for example, has a large net investment in other countries due to its role as an international financial center.

docs.title: International Investments and Debts
docs.text:
• Foreign countries invest hundreds of billions of dollars more in other countries than they receive in investments from those countries.
  • Neither international deficits nor surpluses are inevitable consequences of prosperity or poverty.
  • The words debt and deficit do not necessarily convey information about a country's economic condition.

docs.title: Types of Debts
docs.text:
• Not all debts are created equal; some may present problems, while others do not.
  • For example, when you deposit money in a bank, the bank goes deeper into debt because it owes you that money.
  • A bank's growing debt can be a sign of increased deposits and business activity, rather than financial trouble.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: International investments and debts are complex issues that require careful consideration of individual circumstances. Neither creditor nor debtor status is inherently good or bad, and the words debt and deficit should not be used to make assumptions about a country's economic condition.

docs.title: Notes on Debt and Economic Growth
Key Points
docs.text:
• Buying on credit can lead to debt beyond one's means of repayment, causing trouble.
  • Banks, however, benefit from large deposits, even if it means going deeper in debt, as they can make more loans and earn interest.

docs.title: Historical Context: United States as a Debtor Nation
docs.text:
• The US has been a debtor nation for most of its history.
  • Despite this, the country has maintained a high standard of living.
  • An influx of capital from Western Europe, particularly Britain, helped develop the American economy in the 19th century.

docs.title: Impact of Foreign Investment on Economic Growth
docs.text:
• Foreign investment enabled the US to build infrastructure such as canals, factories, and transcontinental railroads.
  • Examples:
    • In the 1890s, foreign investors owned significant portions of railroad stocks, including:
      • One-fifth of Baltimore & Ohio Railroad stock
      • Over one-third of New York Central stock
      • More than half of Pennsylvania Railroad stock
      • Nearly two-thirds of Illinois Central stock

docs.title: Current State of Foreign Ownership in the US
docs.text:
• Even today, foreigners own more assets in the US than Americans own abroad.
  • American multinational corporations have significant holdings in other countries.

docs.title: Page 772
docs.text: Summary Notes

docs.title: Historical Context
docs.text:
• The US has been a debtor nation for most of its history, with foreign investors sending money to America since 1986.
  • American entrepreneurs only accepted these investments if they expected them to generate sufficient returns to cover interest and dividends.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Foreign investment played a significant role in the development of specific sectors, such as industry and infrastructure.
  • However, its overall importance should not be exaggerated, even in the 19th century.
  • Estimated foreign investment financed around 6% of all capital formation in the US during the 19th century.

docs.title: Notable Exceptions
docs.text: • Railroads were an exception, accounting for a majority of foreign investments in American enterprises.

docs.title: Foreign Investment and Economic Growth
docs.text:
• The role of foreign investors varies across countries, with some economies receiving more investments in absolute amounts.
  • Examples:
    • Overseas investors owned 1/5 of the Australian economy and 1/2 of Argentina's economy in the early 20th century.
    • Massive infusion of foreign capital contributed to making the United States the world's leading industrial nation by 1913.

docs.title: Economic Transactions are Not Zero-Sum
docs.text:
• Everyone can win when investments create a growing economy.
  • A bigger pie means everyone can get bigger slices.
  • Example:
    • Americans have one of the world's highest standards of living despite foreigners carrying away vast amounts of wealth from the United States.

docs.title: Economic Reality Behind Accounting Terms
docs.text:
• Terms like debt may have different economic realities behind them in different countries.
  • Example:
    • When exports will not cover the cost of imports, high-tech knowledge and innovation are required to create wealth.

Key Takeaways

  1. Foreign investment can contribute significantly to a country's economic growth.
  2. Economic transactions are not zero-sum; everyone can win when investments create a growing economy.
  3. Accounting terms may have different economic realities behind them in different countries.

docs.title: Trade Deficits and Debts
docs.text:
• A large trade deficit or payments deficit does not necessarily create a crisis.
  • The government can borrow money from other countries or international agencies to cover the difference.
  • These debts are genuine causes for concern.

docs.title: Zero-Sum Contest Assumption
docs.text:
• Many people assume that international trade is a zero-sum contest, where one country's gain must come at another country's loss.
  • This assumption is implicit in much confused thinking about international trade and wealth transfers.

docs.title: Multinational Corporations and Investment
docs.text:
• Most American investments abroad go to richer countries with high wage rates, not poorer countries.
  • From 1994 to 2002, more US direct investment went to Canada and European nations than the entire rest of the world combined.
  • US investments in poverty-stricken areas like sub-Saharan Africa and parts of Asia are about one percent of worldwide foreign investment by Americans.
  • Most jobs created abroad by American multinational companies have been in high-wage countries.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
• The assumption of a zero-sum contest is flawed, and international trade can be mutually beneficial.
  • Investment and job creation patterns do not support the idea that multinational corporations exploit workers in poorer countries.

docs.title: Summary Notes
docs.text:
International Investments and Wages

  • The United States is the largest recipient of international investments despite high wages for American workers.
  • Companies like India's Tata conglomerate invest in Western nations with higher wages, rather than low-wage countries.

Why Companies Invest in High-Wage Countries

  • Profit-seeking companies prioritize investment in affluent industrial nations over sweatshop labor in Third World countries.
  • This contradicts the idea of exploiting poor workers for cheap labor.

Facts vs. Exploitation Narrative

  • The exploitation narrative does not fit the facts about where profit-seeking enterprises invest their money.
  • Multinational corporations tend to avoid investing in the poorest countries, even within developing nations.

Multinational Corporations and Employment

  • American multinational corporations alone employ over 30 million people worldwide.
  • However, relatively few of these jobs are likely to be in the poorest countries where they are most needed.

docs.title: Low Wages in Less Developed Countries
docs.text:
• Lower wages can compensate for lower productivity, higher shipping costs, and bribes paid to government officials.
  • Protest movements in affluent countries may push for higher wages and better working conditions, but this could lead to:
    • Fewer foreign companies investing in the Third World
    • Fewer jobs for Third World workers

docs.title: Consequences of Increased Wages
docs.text:
• Multinational corporations typically pay double the local wages in poor countries.
  • Losing these jobs could translate into more hardship for Third World workers, despite efforts to end exploitation.

docs.title: Other Forms of Wealth Transfer
docs.text: • Remittances, foreign aid, and other forms of wealth transfer remain significant alongside international investments.

docs.title: Summary Notes: Transfers of Human Capital
Remittances
docs.text:
• Emigrants working abroad often send money back to their families in their home country.
  • During the 19th and early 20th centuries, Italian emigrant men were known for enduring harsh conditions to send money back to Italy.
  • Remittances played a significant role in helping people flee famine in Ireland during the 1840s and Jewish emigrants from Eastern Europe.

docs.title: Impact of Remittances
docs.text:
• In the 21st century, remittances are a major source of outside money flowing into poorer countries.
  • In 2009, worldwide remittances to these countries were over 2.5 times the value of all foreign aid.
  • Overseas Chinese living in Southeast Asia have historically sent significant amounts of money back to their families in China.

docs.title: Misconceptions about Remittances
docs.text:
• Politicians and journalists in some host countries have claimed that remittances are impoverishing their nations for the benefit of China, but this is not supported by evidence.
  • In reality, overseas Chinese have created many enterprises and contributed significantly to the economies of their host countries.

docs.title: The Wealth Created by Immigrant Groups
docs.text:
• Immigrant groups have been accused of sending wealth back to their home countries, but this is only a fraction of the wealth they created in their host countries.
  • Examples include:
    • Southeast Asian nations creating industries and adding wealth to their host countries
    • Lebanese in West Africa, Indians and Pakistanis in East Africa, and other groups around the world

docs.title: The Fallacy of Ignoring Wealth Creation
docs.text:
• The underlying fallacy is ignoring the wealth created by these immigrant groups.
  • Host countries have more wealth, not less, as a result of these groups being there.

docs.title: Consequences of Hostility towards Immigrant Groups
docs.text:
• Hostility has led to some groups leaving or being expelled from their host countries.
  • This has often been followed by economic declines in the countries left behind.

docs.title: The Importance of Immigrants in Creating Wealth
docs.text:
• People are one of the biggest sources of wealth.
  • Whole industries have been created and economies transformed by immigrants.
  • Examples include:
    • German immigrants creating leading beer breweries in the United States
    • Germans creating China's most famous beer, Tsingtao, and establishing breweries in Australia, Brazil, and Argentina.

docs.title: Immigration and Industrial Development
docs.text:
Key Points

  • The Huguenots' flight from France to England and Switzerland led to the transfer of watch-making skills, making both nations leading watch-makers.
  • Immigrant groups played a crucial role in the rise of Britain and the United States as industrial and commercial powers.
  • Foreign workers and entrepreneurs revolutionized various industries in England, including:
    • Woolen
    • Linen
    • Cotton
    • Silk
    • Paper
    • Glass

Notable Examples

  • Germans pioneered piano-building in colonial America and continued to produce leading American pianos, such as Steinway.
  • Jews and Lombards developed British financial institutions.

Impact on Latin America

  • Countries in the region have been heavily dependent on immigrants from countries other than Spain and Portugal.
  • Immigration has played a significant role in shaping the industries and occupations of Latin American nations.

docs.title: Notes on Price Controls and Shortages
The San Francisco Earthquake Example
docs.text:
• After the 1906 earthquake, 200,000 people were left homeless.
  • Despite this, there was no housing shortage reported in newspapers at the time.
  • Rising prices allocated existing housing and provided incentives for rebuilding and using less space.

Key Points

  • A shortage can exist without a physical scarcity (e.g., rent control laws).
  • A greater physical scarcity does not necessarily mean a shortage (e.g., San Francisco earthquake example).

docs.title: Hoarding under Price Controls
docs.text:
• Price controls can lead to hoarding, where individuals keep larger inventories of goods due to uncertainty about future availability.
  • Example: Gasoline shortages in the 1970s led to motorists stockpiling gas.

Consequences of Price Controls

  • Shortages
  • Quality deterioration
  • Hoarding

Overall, price controls can have unintended consequences, such as shortages and hoarding. Understanding these effects is crucial for policymakers and individuals alike.

docs.title: The Impact of Immigration on National Economies
Key Points
docs.text:
• Immigrants have played a significant role in shaping the economies of various countries, including Brazil, Argentina, Chile, and others.
  • Foreigners have owned or directed more than half of particular industries in several countries, such as Lebanese in West Africa, Greeks in the Ottoman Empire, Germans in Brazil, and Indians in Fiji.

docs.title: Examples of Immigrant Contributions
docs.text:
• Cambodians own four-fifths of the doughnut shops in California.
  • Chinese immigrants have contributed significantly to the economy of Malaysia.
  • Belgians have played a major role in Russia's economy.

docs.title: National Economic Losses from Emigration
docs.text:
• The expulsion of Moriscos from Spain in the 17th century led to significant economic losses, including the loss of skilled laborers such as shoemakers.
  • Some countries have exported human capital on a large scale, with educated young people emigrating to other countries for better opportunities.

docs.title: Statistics
docs.text:
• More than 60% of college or university graduates in Fiji, Trinidad, Haiti, Jamaica, and Guyana have emigrated to OECD countries.
  • In Guyana, 83% of graduates have emigrated to OECD countries.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: Immigration has had a profound impact on national economies throughout history. While some countries have benefited from immigration, others have suffered significant economic losses due to emigration. Understanding the complex dynamics of immigration and its effects on national economies is crucial for informed policy-making.

docs.title: The Impact of Emigration
docs.text:
• Large-scale emigration of educated individuals can represent a significant loss of national wealth.
  • Example: Nazi Germany's anti-Semitic policies led to the emigration of Jewish scientists, who later contributed to the development of the atomic bomb in the United States.

docs.title: The Economic Impact of Immigration
docs.text:
• Immigration has both positive and negative economic impacts.
  • Positive contributions:
    • Skilled immigrants can drive innovation and economic growth.
  • Negative consequences:
    • Immigrants have brought diseases, crime, internal strife, and terrorism to host countries.

docs.title: Variations in Immigration Patterns
docs.text:
• Not all immigrants can be lumped together; patterns vary by country of origin.
  • Examples:
    • 2% of Japanese immigrants to the United States rely on welfare, compared to 46% of Laotian immigrants.
    • Disparities in crime rates and other factors exist among immigrants from different countries.

docs.title: Corruption and Crime Among Immigrants
docs.text: • Immigrants from corrupt countries (e.g., Russia and Nigeria) have been associated with high levels of criminal activity in the United States.

docs.title: Definition and History
docs.text:
• Imperialism refers to the plunder of one nation or people by another.
  • It has been a common occurrence throughout human history.

docs.title: Non-Economic Reasons for Imperialism
docs.text:
• Military leaders may want strategic locations, such as bases in Gibraltar or Guantanamo Bay.
  • Nineteenth century missionaries urged governments to acquire control of countries in Africa where there was missionary work.
  • Private individuals, like Cecil Rhodes, may have personal interests in imperialism.

docs.title: Economic Impact of Imperialism
docs.text:
• The costs of establishing and maintaining colonial regimes often exceeded the wealth gained from them.
  • Modern European imperialism controlled large territories, but with limited economic significance.

docs.title: Statistics on European Imperialism
docs.text:
• Western Europe controlled 40% of the world's land area through overseas empires at its zenith in the early twentieth century.
  • Despite this, most major industrial nations sent only trivial percentages of their exports to these colonies.

docs.title: Summary Notes
docs.text:
Industrial Nations and Colonial Investments

  • Industrial nations invested more in other industrial countries than in their conquered colonies in the Third World.
  • Examples:
    • Britain invested more in the US than in all of Asia and Africa combined during the height of the British Empire.
    • The US invested more in Canada than in all of Asia and Africa combined throughout most of the 20th century.

Wealth Attraction

  • Wealthy countries attract more investment than poor countries.
  • The rise of prosperous Asian industrial nations in the late 20th century attracted more American investors.
  • Foreign investments poured into oil-producing Middle Eastern countries after the world price of oil skyrocketed in the early 21st century.

Evidence Against Economic Significance of Colonies

  • Germany and Japan lost all their colonies after WWII, yet rebounded to unprecedented levels of prosperity.
  • This suggests that a need for colonies is not economically significant in the modern world.

docs.title: Summary Notes
docs.text:
Imperialism and Economic Development

  • Japan's economic prosperity was achieved through buying natural resources from other countries, rather than relying on imperialism.
  • Imperialism has caused suffering among conquered peoples, but it is not a major source of international wealth transfer in the modern industrial world.

Foreign Investment and Poverty

  • Foreign investment in poor countries is often portrayed as exploitation, but in reality, it can lead to economic growth and prosperity for both investors and host countries.
  • The absence of foreign investment in less developed countries has led to higher poverty rates.
  • Countries with more international trade have experienced higher economic growth rates.

Globalization and Economic Growth

  • Poor countries that are more globalized (i.e., have a larger percentage of international trade) have had growing economies, while those with less globalization have experienced declining economies.

Wealthy Individuals' Investment Behavior

  • Wealthy individuals in poor countries often invest in richer countries, rather than in their own country.

docs.title: Global Investment and Economic Imperialism
docs.text:
• Richer industrial nations invest in poorer countries, making them still richer
  • Poorer countries initially pursued policies that discouraged foreign investments due to fears of economic imperialism
  • By the late 20th century, the negative consequences of these policies became apparent, leading some governments (e.g., Latin America and India) to open up to foreign investments

docs.title: Economic Realities vs. Ideological Visions
docs.text:
• Economic realities eventually broke through ideological visions, but not before generations suffered from poverty
  • Basic economic facts and principles were finally accepted, leading to an influx of foreign goods and investments in previously closed markets

docs.title: Impact of Foreign Investments in Poorer Countries
docs.text:
• Small investments from prosperous countries loomed large in poorer countries due to their relative poverty
  • As of 1991, foreign companies owned 27% of businesses in Latin America; a decade later, this trend continued.

docs.title: Misconceptions about Economic Activity
docs.text:
• Many economic fallacies arise from viewing economic activity as a zero-sum contest, where one person's gain is another person's loss.
  • This misconception often stems from ignoring the fact that wealth is created during economic activity.

docs.title: Foreign Investment and National Wealth
docs.text:
• Payments to foreign investors do not necessarily impoverish a nation.
  • The United States, for example, had $543 billion taken out of its economy by foreigners in 2012, but this was still a small fraction of the country's overall wealth.
  • Americans had already benefited from the additional wealth created by these foreign-owned assets and were simply sharing part of that wealth with their foreign contributors.

docs.title: International Trade and Inequality
docs.text:
• The claim that free international trade increases inequality between rich and poor nations is based on misleading statistics.
  • Comparing the same twenty highest-income and lowest-income nations in 1960 and 2000 shows that the ratio of income between them actually decreased, not increased.
