docs.text: The following notes summarize key points from a chapter on economics, covering topics such as pricing, mercantilism, branding, and the role of profit motive.

docs.title: 1. Pricing of Identical Products
docs.text:
• Different prices are charged for physically identical products due to various reasons.
  • See pages 572-573 for more information.

docs.title: 2. Mercantilist Economists vs. Classical Economists
docs.text:
• Mercantilist economists differed from classical economists, such as Adam Smith, in their views on economics.
  • See pages 598-601 for more information.

docs.title: 3. Branding and Quality
docs.text:
• Having different brands of the same product may not necessarily imply differences in quality.
  • If laws were to eliminate branding, allowing consumers to only identify products but not manufacturers, it could lead to changes in consumer behavior.
  • See pages 574-578 for more information.

docs.title: 4. Relative Prices and Production Costs
docs.text:
• For about a century (1770s-1870s), economists believed that relative prices of goods reflected their relative costs of production, especially labor required.
  • This theory has several problems; see pages 607-611 for more information.

docs.title: 5. Profit Motive and Organizational Purpose
docs.text:
• The presence or absence of profit motive affects an organization's likelihood of achieving its purpose to the maximum extent possible with available resources.
  • See pages 578-580 for more information.

docs.title: 6. Racial Discrimination in Employment
docs.text:
• In the era before laws against racial discrimination in employment, black chemists may have been more likely to be hired in non-profit organizations than profit-making businesses.
  • This is due to the different incentives and priorities of these types of organizations.

docs.title: Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Pricing of identical products can vary due to several reasons.
  • The presence or absence of profit motive can impact an organization's ability to achieve its purpose.
  • Eliminating branding could lead to changes in consumer behavior.

docs.title: Initial Reactions
docs.text:
• Price controls are often viewed favorably by the public when first imposed.
  • Ordinary citizens may initially greet price cuts with euphoria, leading to a short-lived shopping spree.

docs.title: Consequences of Price Controls
docs.text:
• Hospital patients die due to lack of basic medical supplies.
  • Power blackouts and water cutoffs become endemic.
  • Price controls lead to shortages and misallocation of resources.

docs.title: Natural Disasters and Price Gouging
docs.text:
• In the aftermath of a natural disaster, prices may rise for essential goods such as bottled water, flashlights, and gasoline.
  • Many people consider it unconscionable if businesses raise prices in this situation.
  • Politicians often respond by passing laws against price gouging.

docs.title: The Role of Prices
docs.text:
• Prices play a crucial role in allocating scarce resources.
  • This role is even more urgently needed when local resources become scarce due to increased demand after a natural disaster.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
• Price controls may provide short-term relief but lead to long-term consequences such as shortages and misallocation of resources.
  • Understanding the role of prices in allocating scarce resources is essential for making informed decisions, especially in times of crisis.

docs.title: Page 982
docs.text:
Notes on Soviet Union Economy

The Soviet Union's economy was plagued by inefficiencies and shortages, leading to:

  • Long lines and waiting times: People waited for hours or even days to purchase basic goods like tomatoes, men's undershirts, and other essentials.
  • Shortages of essential goods: The lack of supply led to scarcity of everyday items, forcing people to wait in long lines.

Examples

  • A visitor to the Soviet Union in 1987 reported seeing long lines of people waiting to buy tomatoes from a cardboard box.
  • Outside a shop next to their hotel, there was a line for three days due to a new shipment of men's undershirts.

Related Issues

  • Bureaucratic inefficiencies: Similar problems can occur when aid arrives by land, leading to delays and even starvation (e.g., Afghan refugees dying while waiting for paperwork to be completed).
  • Economic revitalization efforts: The Soviet Union attempted to revitalize its economy through initiatives like The Turning Point: Revitalizing the Soviet Economy in 1989.

docs.title: Notes on Rent Control and Government Regulations
Observations on Landlords
docs.text:

  • This challenges the assumption that landlords are wealthy and exploitative

docs.title: Unintended Consequences of Rent Control
docs.text:

  • Black markets can emerge as a sideline of legitimate businesses

docs.title: Patterns in Government Programs
docs.text:

  • Regulations can lead to unintended consequences, including black markets and exploitation

docs.title: Warning: Handling Regulations Requires Expertise
docs.text:
• Just as professional chemists require safeguards when handling dangerous chemicals, policymakers need expertise when designing regulations
  • Amateur attempts at regulation can be fatal (to the economy or individuals)

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:

  • When a need for a loan arises, no application may be required; the borrower can simply write checks exceeding their account balance.
  • The bank covers the overdraft with minimal time and trouble due to pre-established credit.

docs.title: Benefits
docs.text:

  • Low risk and cost for the bank compared to check-cashing companies

docs.text:

  • However, men who already consumed 7 or more drinks/week experienced an increase in cardiovascular disease with further drinking.

Source: Archives of Internal Medicine (September 25, 2000 issue)

docs.title: Component Suppliers in a Market Economy
docs.text:
• Despite the efficiency of market economies, component suppliers can still fail to deliver.
  • This can lead to significant delays and costs, even for large companies like Boeing and Airbus.

Example: Boeing and Airbus Delays

  • Planes worth hundreds of millions of dollars have been left idle due to missing components such as galleys (kitchens) and toilets.
  • Executives from both companies have expressed frustration with the delays, with one Boeing official stating that they had a huge asset that was not moving.

Key Point: Pressures for Correction

  • While human shortcomings exist in all economic systems, market economies provide pressures to force corrections.
  • Large customers can exert significant influence on suppliers to resolve issues and prevent future delays.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Michaels, D., & Lunsford, J. (2008). Lack of Seats, Galleys Delays Boeing, Airbus. Wall Street Journal, pp. B1, B4.

docs.title: Cartel Pricing System
docs.text:
• The cartel set a fixed price for steel based on production costs plus shipping costs by rail from Pittsburgh.
  • This pricing system was applied uniformly across the United States, regardless of actual production location or shipping method.

docs.title: Rationale
docs.text:
• Prevented individual producers from hiding price reductions in variable freight charges.
  • Made it easier to monitor and enforce cartel-agreed prices.

docs.title: Consequences
docs.text:
• Led to a misallocation of resources due to uniform pricing across different locations.
  • Encouraged inefficient production and transportation patterns.

docs.title: How Prices Help Ration Scarce Goods During Emergencies
docs.text:
• When demand for local hotel rooms or other goods increases suddenly, and supply remains constant, these goods must be rationed.
  • If prices remain the same as in normal times:
    • Those who arrive first will take all available goods.
    • Others may have to go without or leave the area.
  • If prices rise sharply (price gouging):
    • People will have incentives to ration themselves.
    • Example: A family might rent only one hotel room instead of multiple rooms.

docs.title: Examples of Rationing
docs.text:
• Hotel rooms:
    • Normal prices: First-come, first-served; others may be left without a room.
    • High prices (price gouging): Families will have an incentive to share a single room.
  • Flashlights during a power outage:
    • Normal prices: Those who arrive first at stores will buy all available flashlights; others will go without.
    • High prices (price gouging): People will be more likely to buy only what they need.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Prices can help ration scarce goods during emergencies.
  • Price increases (price gouging) can provide incentives for people to conserve resources.

docs.title: Notes on Steel Transportation
docs.text:
• Rail freight costs from Pittsburgh affected steel transportation
  • Steel was transported over longer distances due to these costs
  • This resulted in an unnatural increase in steel transportation compared to a free, competitive market

docs.title: Minimum Wage Increase: Impact on Employment
docs.text:
Scenario

  • 10 firms in an industry, each hiring 1,000 workers before a minimum wage increase
  • 3 firms go out of business after the increase, and only 1 new firm enters the industry

Key Points

  • Industry employment decreases: From 10,000 to 8,800 employees (12% decrease)
  • Employment per firm may increase: Surviving firms hire more workers (e.g., 1,100 each), despite industry-wide decrease
  • Biased survey results: Studying only surviving firms shows a 10% increase in employment, masking the true 12% industry-wide decrease

Effects of Minimum Wage Increase

  1. Reducing employment among all firms
  2. Pushing marginal firms into bankruptcy
  3. Discouraging entry of replacement firms

Conclusion

Surveys based on surviving firms can be misleading, as they do not account for the impact of minimum wage increases on industry-wide employment and firm dynamics.

docs.title: Notes on Government and Private Sector Interaction
Outsourcing of Government Functions
docs.text:
• Some state and local governments outsource functions like garbage collection and running prisons to private businesses.
  • The federal government also outsources some functions to private companies, both domestically and internationally.

docs.title: Limitations of Outsourcing
docs.text:

  • There are exceptions to virtually every rule, and unexpected events can disrupt even seemingly safe investments.

docs.title: Example: California's Electricity Crisis
docs.text:

  • The state forced utilities to sell electricity at a loss, leading to billions of dollars in debt and downgraded bond ratings.

docs.title: Summary of Economic Repercussions of Eliminating Mandatory Retirement Age
Key Points
docs.text:
• Elimination of mandatory retirement age led to:
    • Reduced opportunities for younger workers to advance in their careers
    • Inefficient use of labor, as older employees may not be as productive
  • Employers faced increased costs and risks in proving productivity decline to avoid age discrimination lawsuits
  • Older employees who did not experience productivity decline could have already been retained by employers on an individual basis

docs.title: Economic Implications
docs.text:
• Loss of efficiency for the economy as a whole due to reduced labor mobility
  • Potential misallocation of labor, with older workers being kept employed when younger workers could perform duties more efficiently

docs.text:
• Four classes of income:
    • $1,000/year

docs.title: Gresham's Law
docs.text:
• Bad money drives out good money from circulation.
  • Example: In a POW camp, unpopular cigarette brands were used as currency, while popular ones were consumed.

docs.title: Smoot-Hawley Tariffs
docs.text:
• The tariffs may have contributed more to the massive unemployment of the 1930s than the stock market crash of 1929.
  • Unemployment rates:
    • Did not reach 10% in the 12 months following the stock market crash.
    • Reached 11.6% just five months after the Smoot-Hawley tariff and remained high for over eight years.

docs.text: • Richard K Vedder and Lowell E Gallaway, Out of Work, 1993 edition, p. 77.

docs.text: • See Michael Harrington's discussion on urban hillbillies in The Other America, 1962 edition, pp. 96-100.

docs.title: Arabic Numerals
docs.text:
• Westerners referred to them as Arabic numerals because they were first encountered in use among Arabs.
  • However, the Arabs got these numbers from India.

docs.title: Geographic Location and Genius
docs.text:
• Geographic location alone cannot create genius, but it can provide opportunities for it to emerge and develop.
  • Historic achievements have been concentrated geographically, often in non-isolated areas.

docs.title: Food Storage and Innovation
docs.text: • The need to store food, especially in winter, drives innovation (e.g., turning perishable milk into storable cheese).

docs.title: Economic Inequality and Cultural Access
docs.text:
• Elites in Arab countries who speak English or other languages have access to a larger cultural universe than the masses.
  • The lack of translated writings exacerbates economic and social inequalities within these countries.
  • This also widens the economic gap between these countries and the Western world.

docs.title: Blame and Cultural Context
docs.text:
• The concept of blame is questionable when individuals are born into a specific culture, geographic setting, and historical period without choice.
  • This challenges the idea of personal responsibility for one's cultural context.

docs.title: Agriculture and Social Evolution
docs.text:
• The advent of agriculture marked a significant advance in human social evolution, enabling larger and more complex societies.
  • However, early farmers were not immediately aware of the need to replenish soil nutrients.

docs.title: Early Agricultural Challenges
docs.text:
• Agricultural methods at the time made permanent settlement of large populations impossible in most areas.
  • Only river valleys with annual floods that fertilized fields allowed for continuous farming over years.

docs.title: Geographic Advantages
docs.text:
• The Tigris and Euphrates rivers in modern-day Iraq created favorable conditions for early agriculture.
  • This led to economic inequalities between those living in this region and others.

docs.title: Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Early agriculture was not without its challenges, including soil nutrient depletion.
  • Geographic location played a significant role in determining the success of early agricultural societies.
